revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1871 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – none '''Events''' * The [[1871 college football season]] is the only one since the first season in [[1869 college football season|1869]] until the present day that no games are played in the entire season.<ref>[http://www.collegefootballblog.org/2006/03/national_champions_18691879.html "National Champions: 1869–1879"]. Jimmy Atkinson. ''Retrospective National Championship Project''. College Football Blog. 20 March 2006.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-game.org/history-waltercamp.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-04-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130405055140/http://www.the-game.org/history-waltercamp.htm |archivedate=2013-04-05 |df= }}. history-waltercamp.htm (''the-game.org''). <!-- archive fileserver is down; URL seems to be http://web.archive.org/web/20130405055140/http://www.the-game.org/history-waltercamp.htm --></ref> Thus 1871 is the only year since play began in which no [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|college football national champion]] can be named, retrospectively or otherwise.
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * Inaugural [[FA Cup]] competition begins with four matches played on 11 November. The 15 clubs entering the competition are all amateur and mainly from the London area: [[Barnes R.F.C.|Barnes]], Civil Service, [[Clapham Rovers F.C.|Clapham Rovers]], [[Crystal Palace F.C. (1861)|Crystal Palace (1861)]], Donnington School, Hampstead Heathens, Harrow Chequers, Hitchin, Maidenhead, Marlow, Reigate, Priory, [[Royal Engineers A.F.C.|Royal Engineers]], [[Upton Park F.C.|Upton Park]], [[Wanderers F.C.|The Wanderers]] and [[Queen's Park FC|Queen's Park]] (Glasgow). : The Wanderers win the Cup on 16 March 1872.
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National Association of Professional Base Ball Players]] champion – [[Philadelphia Athletics (National League)|Philadelphia Athletics]] '''Events''' * March — ten [[NABBP]] clubs found the [[National Association of Professional Base Ball Players]], the first [[professional sports league organization|professional sports league]]. (Today it is commonly considered the first [[Major League Baseball|major league]] and usually called simply the "National Association" or "NA".) Thirty-three clubs establish a parallel amateur NAABBP that withers away. * There are nine NA teams in the field and [[Philadelphia Athletics (National Association)|Athletic]] of Philadelphia wins the championship in the final game, 30 October.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * With the main American Championship title claimant [[Mike McCoole]] inactive this year, attention focuses on two fights between [[Jem Mace]] and [[Joe Coburn]]. Both fights are drawn and Mace continues to state his claim to the American Championship. However, having suffered a hand injury in his second fight with Coburn, Mace relinquishes all his title claims and returns to exhibition boxing.<ref name="JM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/mace-j.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Jem Mace]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * McCoole is now generally regarded as the champion by default, his main challenger being [[Tom Allen (boxer)|Tom Allen]] who was defeated by McCoole in 1869.<ref name="MM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/mccoole.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Mike McCoole]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club|Derbyshire]] plays its inaugural [[first-class cricket|first-class]] match v. [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]] at [[Old Trafford Cricket Ground|Old Trafford]] on 26 & 27 May. '''England''' * Most runs – [[W. G. Grace]] 2,739 @ 78.25 (HS 268), a staggering feat on the pitches of the time. [[Richard Daft]] has the next highest average among batsmen playing 10 innings or more, with 37.66, less than half of Grace's figure. [[Harry Jupp]] has the next highest runs aggregate, with 1,068. Grace makes ten centuries in the season, while no other player can manage more than one. * Most wickets – [[James Southerton]] 151 @ 15.72 (BB 8–63)
==[[Gaelic football]]== * During the 1860s and 1870s, rugby and association football have started to become popular in Ireland. According to Gaelic football historian [[Jack Mahon (Gaelic footballer)|Jack Mahon]], [[caid (sport)|caid]] has begun to give way to a "rough-and-tumble game" which even allows tripping. * [[County Limerick]] is the stronghold of the native game around this time and the Commercials Club, founded by employees of Cannock's Drapery Store, is one of the first to impose a set of rules that is later adopted by other clubs in the county.
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[The Open Championship|British Open]] – no competition. * The Open has been administered since 1860 by [[Prestwick Golf Club]] but controversy prevents the tournament being held in 1871, the only exception outside the two World Wars. Finally it is agreed that Prestwick will henceforth organise the tournament jointly with [[The Royal & Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews]] and [[The Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers]].
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1871 Grand National|Grand National]] – The Lamb (second win, having also won in 1868) * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Hannah (horse)|Hannah]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Bothwell * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Favonius (horse)|Favonius]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Hannah * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Hannah '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – The Pearl '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Floss '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – The Doe * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Maid of Athens '''USA''' * [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Harry Bassett (horse)|Harry Bassett]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 1 April — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 28th [[The Boat Race 1871|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] '''Other''' * There is no [[Harvard–Yale Regatta]]. From the third Race in 1859, the only exceptions outside major wars are 1871 and 1896.
==[[Rugby football]]== '''Events''' * 26 January — the [[Rugby Football Union]] (RFU) is founded at the Pall Mall Restaurant, which is situated near [[Trafalgar Square]] at 1 Cockspur Street, London. The formation of the RFU establishes the "handling game" as a different sport to the "[[association football|dribbling game]]" that is increasingly being played under the auspices of [[the Football Association]]. * 21 clubs are represented at the meeting: Blackheath, Richmond, Ravenscourt Park, West Kent, Marlborough Nomads, Wimbledon Hornets, Gipsies, Civil Service, Law Club, Wellington College, Guy's Hospital, Flamingoes, Clapham Rovers, Harlequins, King's College, St Paul's School, Queen's House, Lausanne, Addison, Mohicans, [[Belsize Park Rugby Football Club|Belsize Park]]. Algernon Rutter of Richmond is elected the first president. A committee is selected to produce a definitive national set of Rugby Football laws. * 27 March — the [[1871 England versus Scotland rugby union match|first ever official international fixture]] in any kind of football takes place with a rugby football game between Scotland and England. Scotland (i.e., Scottish members of the RFU) defeats England (i.e., English members of the RFU) by 1 goal & 1 try to 1 try at Raeburn Place in Edinburgh. The match is played by teams of 20–a–side and the game lasts for 50 minutes each way. * Foundation of [[Worcester RFC]]
==[[Yacht racing]]== '''America's Cup''' * The [[New York Yacht Club]] retains the [[America's Cup]] as ''[[Columbia (1871 yacht)|Columbia]]'' and its substitute ''[[Sappho (yacht)|Sappho]]'' defeat British challenger ''Livonia'' of the Royal Harwich Yacht Club.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}

The defending regular season and tournament champion was [[North Florida Ospreys men's basketball|North Florida]]. It was the first season in the A-Sun for [[NJIT Highlanders men's basketball|NJIT]], who replaced [[Northern Kentucky Norse men's basketball|Northern Kentucky]] following their departure for the [[Horizon League]]. North Florida won their second straight regular season championship but were upset by Florida Gulf Coast in the [[2016 Atlantic Sun Men's Basketball Tournament]] semifinals. Florida Gulf Coast defeated Stetson in the Tournament title game to win their second A-Sun Tournament championship and berth in the [[2016 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament]]. ==Postseason results== {| class="wikitable" |- align="center" ! He plays as either a [[Striker (association football)|striker]] or a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]]. ==Career== M'Madi had stints in the youth academies of both [[AS Cannes|Cannes]] and [[RC Lens|Lens]] before joining Evian in 2009.{{cite news |title=M'Madi, de rien à la Ligue 1 |url=http://www.etgfc.com/2011/07/11/m%E2%80%99madi-de-rien-a-la-ligue-1/ |work=[[Evian Thonon Gaillard F.C.]] |accessdate=13 December 2011 |language=French |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815073654/http://www.etgfc.com/2011/07/11/m%E2%80%99madi-de-rien-a-la-ligue-1/ |archive-date=2011-08-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Although born in France, he plays for the [[Comoros national football team|Comoros]] at senior international level and made his international debut on 9 October 2010 in a [[2012 Africa Cup of Nations qualification]] against [[Mozambique national football team|Mozambique]].{{cite news |title=M'Madi: "Je voulais faire des frites, j'ai fait exploser la cuisine!" |url=http://www.lemessager.fr/Dossiers/interview/article_1475917.shtml |work=Le Messager |accessdate=13 December 2011 |language = French}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{LFP|id=mmadi-ali}} * {{Lequipe|35354}} * {{NFT player|40504}} * {{Soccerway|ali-mmadi/107185}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mmadi, Ali}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1990 births]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Marseille]] [[Category:French footballers]] [[Category:French people of Comorian descent]] [[Category:Comorian footballers]] [[Category:Comoros international footballers]] [[Category:Expatriate footballers in France]] [[Category:Association football wingers]] [[Category:Association football forwards]] [[Category:Thonon Évian Savoie F. He formerly competes at [[Rizin Fighting Federation]]. Aliakbari now competes at ACB organization.
== Wrestling career == In 2007–2008, he wrestled for [[Melli Haffari Company Ahvaz Sports Club]] of [[Iranian Premier Wrestling League]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://iawf.ir/Contents/2314/%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%8A%20%D9%83%D8%B4%D8%AA%D9%8A%20%DA%AF%D9%8A%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86%20%D8%AA%D9%8A%D9%85%E2%80%8C%D9%87%D8%A7%D9%8A%20%D8%B4%D8%B1%D9%83%D8%AA%20%D9%83%D9%86%D9%86%D8%AF%D9%87%20%D8%AF%D8%B1%20%D9%84%D9%8A%DA%AF%20%D8%A8%D8%B1%D8%AA%D8%B1%20%D9%81%D8%B1%D9%86%DA%AF%D9%8A-.aspx |work=Iran Wrestling Federation |script-title=fa:اسامي كشتی‌گيران و مربيان تيم‌های شركت‌كننده در ليگ برتر فرنگی جام خليج فارس |accessdate=October 19, 2014 |language=Persian}}</ref>
He missed the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] due to a [[Doping in sport|doping]] suspension.<ref name="reuters" />
In [[2013 World Wrestling Championships – Men's Greco-Roman 120 kg|2013 World Wrestling Championships, 120 kg]] he initially won a gold medal, making him a two-times world champion,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.irna.ir/en/News/80827154/Art_&_Culture/Amir_Ali-Akbari_Greco-Roman_world_champ,_Iran_4th_best |work=[[Islamic Republic News Agency|IRNA]] |title=Amir Ali-Akbari Greco-Roman world champ, Iran 4th best |date=September 23, 2013 |accessdate=October 19, 2014}}</ref> however in December 2013, [[United World Wrestling|International Wrestling Federation, FILA]] banned Aliakbari for life after a second [[Doping in sport|doping]] offence. He was stripped of his gold medal and [[Heiki Nabi]] was moved up to gold.<ref name="reuters">{{cite news |first=Karolos |last=Grohmann |editor=Josh Reich |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/12/14/us-doping-wrestling-akbari-ban-idUSBRE9BD0DR20131214 |work=[[Reuters]] |title=Iran's wrestling world champion Akbari banned for life |date=December 14, 2013 |accessdate=October 19, 2014}}</ref>

==MMA career== In 2014, Aliakbari signed an agreement with the MMA management company, Paradigm Sports Management, based in USA,<ref name="Khabaronline">{{cite news |url=http://www.khabaronline.ir/detail/385724/sport/wrestling |script-title=fa:گفت‌وگو با کشتی‌گیر سابق تیم ملی که می‌خواهد در قفس مرگ آمریکا مبارزه کند/ قهرمان شوم ۱۵ میلیارد می‌گیرم |trans-title=An Interview with former national team wrestler who wants to fight in American death cages |accessdate=October 19, 2014 |work=Khabaronline |language=Persian}}</ref> At the same time, he signed on to train under UFC star [[Mike Swick]] of AKA Thailand in Phuket, Thailand also training alongside UFC fighters [[Mark Hunt]] and [[Soa Palelei]].<ref name="Bloody Elbow" /> He is the first world class Iranian wrestler to pursue an MMA career.<ref name="Bloody Elbow">{{cite news |url=http://www.bloodyelbow.com/2014/10/18/6998341/iranian-wrestling-world-champion-aliakbari-training-for-mma-career-at |work=Bloody Elbow |title=Iranian wrestling world champion Aliakbari training for MMA career at AKA Thailand |date=October 18, 2014 |accessdate=October 19, 2014}}</ref> ===Early career=== Aliakbari made his professional MMA debut in October 2015, defeating Hyung Chul-Lee via TKO in the first round. His second bout came two months later as he defeated Radu Spinghel via TKO in the first round. ===Rizin FF=== In early 2016, it was announced that Aliakbari signed with the Japanese promotion [[Rizin Fighting Federation]]. He made his debuted in September in the first round of the [[2016_in_Rizin_Fighting_Federation#Rizin_Openweight_Grand_Prix_2016_bracket|openweight grand prix]] against Joao Isidoro Almeida. He won the fight via TKO in the first round. Aliakbari was scheduled to face former UFC champion [[Shane Carwin]] in the quarter-finals in December 2016. However, Carwin withdrew from the tournament and he instead faced [[Heath Herring]]. Aliakbari won the bout by unanimous decision. In the final stage of the tournament on December 31, Aliakbari faced Valentin Moldavsky. He won the fight via split decision. He then faced [[Mirko Cro Cop]] in the finals on the same night and lost the fight via knockout. He then defeated Geronimo dos Santos and Tyler King via TKO.
=== ACB === On December 2017 Aliakbari announced departure from Rizin and Joining ACB. His first opponent was Denis Smoldarev, who Aliakbari defeated via KO/TKO at 2:27 of Round 1 on March 24, 2018. He is going to have four opponents in ACB.

revision.text:
The '''Challenge 1934''' was the fourth and last [[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale|FAI]] International Tourist Plane Contest ({{lang-fr|Challenge International de Tourisme}}), that took place between August 28 and September 16, 1934, in [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]]. The four Challenges, from 1929 to 1934, were major aviation events in pre-war Europe. The 1934 Challenge was won by the Polish pilots, who had also won [[Challenge 1932|the previous year]].
[[Image:Challenge1934.jpg|thumb|350px|The opening ceremony, from the left: Polish team, three-aircraft Czechoslovak team, German team. The Italian team had not arrived yet.]]
==Overview== Poland and the [[Polish Aero Club]] organized the contest because a Polish pilot [[Franciszek Żwirko]] had won the [[Challenge 1932|previous Challenge]] in [[1932 in aviation|1932]]. The contest rules were announced in June 1933: like the previous contest, it consisted of three parts: technical trials, a [[rallying|rally]] over [[Europe]] and a maximum speed trial, but there were changes in details. Since one of the aims of the Challenges was to stimulate the development of tourist aircraft, a stress was placed upon aircraft performance and quality, although pilots' skills remained crucial.
The opening ceremony was held at noon on August 28, 1934, at [[Pole Mokotowskie|Mokotowskie field]] in Warsaw (the Italian team was late by two hours due to weather and arrived during the ceremony). During an air show, a Polish fighter [[PZL P.7]]a performing aerobatics crashed, but the pilot survived with injuries.
The number of crews and aircraft that eventually took part in the 1934 Challenge was smaller - 34 compared to 43 in the 1932 Challenge, because the contest was more difficult. The aircraft flew with a two-man crew (pilot and mechanic). Only four countries entered teams for the Challenge in 1934: [[Poland]] (12 crews), [[Germany]] (13 crews), [[Italy]] (6 crews) and [[Czechoslovakia]] (3 crews). The British aviator Walter MacPherson entered the contest in the Polish team. The French team of eight crews resigned from the contest, because a development of a new aircraft, the [[Caudron Simoun|Caudron C.500]] had not finished in time and its weight was too great. The first prize in the Challenge was 100,000 [[French franc]]s, the second 40,000 FF, the third 20,000 FF and the fourth 10,000 FF; 15 other crews would get 6,000 FF.
==Aircraft== The Challenge was to be a contest of tourist aircraft, so competing aircraft had to be able to take at least two persons aboard, take off and land on a short field and cover a distance with a good cruise speed. For this Challenge, all countries designed new aircraft especially to meet the contest demands, the only exception was a single [[de Havilland Puss Moth]] flown by MacPherson, although this had been was modified for the competition. All these aircraft were [[monoplane]]s with 3 or 4 seats in an enclosed cabin, advanced wing design with ([[flap (aircraft)|flaps]] and [[Leading edge slats|slats]] and some other devices) and mixed or metal construction.
[[Image:Pzl26.jpg|thumb|250px|The Polish PZL.26 of Ignacy Giedgowd in the Challenge markings]] Most aircraft were fast [[cantilever]] low-wing monoplanes: the German [[Messerschmitt Bf 108]] (4), [[Fieseler Fi 97]] (5) and [[Klemm Kl 36]] (4), the Polish [[PZL.26]] (5) and the Italian [[Pallavicino PS-1]] (2) or braced low-wing monoplanes: the Czechoslovak [[Aero A.200]] (2) and the Italian [[Breda Ba.39]] (2) and [[Breda Ba.42|Ba.42]] (2). An exception were the basic aircraft of the Polish team - high-wing braced monoplanes [[RWD-9]] (7), one of which was also flown by the Czechoslovak crew, and the Puss Moth. Of those, the Bf 108 and PS-1 had a retractable [[landing gear]].
The German aircraft had starting numbers from a range 12-26, the Italian 41-46, the Czechoslovak 51-54 and the Polish 61-81: the numbers were placed on the fuselage in a black square frame.
==Technical trials== On August 29 the technical evaluation of the competing aircraft's construction started. Since it was a tourist aircraft contest, features such as a comfortable cabin with a good view, the presence of the third and fourth seats, seats placed side-by-side, a comprehensive set of controls, ease and time of engine starting, ease of wings' folding, safety devices and modern construction with the use of metal were awarded points. The view was evaluated by placing a lamp in the cabin while the aircraft was in a dark hangar and examining light area. All the German aircraft, two Italian and the Puss Moth exceeded theempty weight limit of {{convert|560.56| kg|lb|abbr=on}} and had to have some unnecessary parts removed. The first technical trial to be completed was a quick engine starting, carried on 31 August-1 September. Most aircraft scored the maximum 24 points in it.
Technical evaluation lasted until September 4, and the most points were given to the [[Messerschmitt Bf 108|Bf 108]]s (450-452 pts),followed by the [[Pallavicino PS-1]] (438 pts), the [[Fieseler Fi 97|Fi 97]]s (428-431 pts), the [[Aero A.200]] (429 pts) and the [[RWD-9]] (427 pts). The other scores were: [[Klemm Kl 36]] - 394-407 pts, [[PZL.26]] - 383 pts, [[de Havilland Puss Moth|Puss Moth]] - 373 pts and Bredas - 323-346 pts.
On September 3–4 there was a short take off trial, which required the crews to fly over an {{convert|8|m|ft|abbr=on}} high barrier. The best performer was the Czechoslovak Vojtěch Žáček, taking off from the closest distance of {{convert|74.5| m|ft|abbr=on}} (Aero A.200), then Jerzy Bajan (RWD-9) and [[Ján Ambruš]] with the second A.200. The Polish RWD-9s and PZL.26s and the German Fi 97s also performed well, while the Italians and most other German aircraft appeared inferior, with results above {{convert|100| m|ft|sigfig=3|abbr=on}}. For comparison, the best result from the previous Challenge was {{convert|91.6| m|ft||abbr=on}}.
{| cellspacing=8 |- ! colspan=12|Top results of the short take-off trial |- |   || Pilot || country || aircraft || distance   ||points |- |1.||Vojtěch Žáček ||{{CZS}}   || Aero A.200|| 74.5 m ||141 pts |- |2.|| [[Jerzy Bajan]] ||{{POL}}|| RWD-9S||76.1 m|| 140 pts |- |3.||[[Ján Ambruš]] ||{{CZS}}|| Aero A.200||77.6 m||138 pts |- |4.|| Szczepan Grzeszczyk|| {{POL}}||PZL.26||78.2 m||138 pts |- |5.|| Gerhard Hubrich ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Fieseler Fi 97   ||78.3 m||138 pts |}
After the technical evaluation and the short take-off trial, on September 4 the leaders were the Germans flying Bf 108s: [[Theo Osterkamp]] (597 points), [[Werner Junck]] (596 points) and Otto Brindlinger (594 points), then Vojtěch Žáček (A.200, 594 points), Jerzy Bajan (RWD-9, 591 points) and [[Ján Ambruš]] (A.200, 591 points), then German Fi 97s and Polish RWD-9s.
Next, on September 4–5, followed a short landing trial, behind an 8-m high barrier. The best result, {{convert|75 |m|ft|abbr=on}} (210 points) was achieved by [[Hans Seidemann]] (Fi 97). In the first ten scores there were other Fieselers, the Polish RWD-9s and PZL.26s and MacPherson's Puss Moth. The Czechoslovak A.200s had the worst results, above {{convert|117| m|ft|abbr=on}}, along with Bredas and Bf 108s. The best result from the previous Challenge was {{convert|92.4| m|ft}}. {| cellspacing=8 |- ! colspan=12|Top results of the short landing trial |- |   || Pilot || country || aircraft || distance   ||points |- |1.||[[Hans Seidemann]] ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}   ||Fieseler Fi 97   ||75 m||210 pts |- |2.|| Tadeusz Karpiński || {{POL}}||PZL.26||78.2 m||138 pts |- |3.|| Gerhard Hubrich ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Fieseler Fi 97||79 m||206 pts |- |4.|| Andrzej Włodarkiewicz || {{POL}}||PZL.26||79.7 m||205 pts |- |5.|| [[Jerzy Bajan]] ||{{POL}}|| RWD-9S||79.8 m||205 pts |- |6.|| Walter MacPherson ||{{POL}} / {{UK}}|| [[de Havilland Puss Moth|DH-80A]]||80.8 m||203 pts |}
A fuel consumption trial on a {{convert|594|km|mi|abbr=on}} closed circuit was held on September 5. The best were three [[Messerschmitt Bf 108|Bf 108]]s, scoring 86-95 pts, then five Poles with 73-79 points. Quite good results were scored by the Italians, while the German Fi 97s and Kl 36s and the Czechoslovaks were worst in this trial. {| cellspacing=8 |- ! colspan=12|Top results of the fuel consumption trial |- |   || Pilot || country || aircraft || kg/100 km   ||points |- |1.||Karl Francke ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}   ||Bf 108A||10.5||95 pts |- |2.||[[Werner Junck]] ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Bf 108A||11.07||90 pts |- |3.||[[Theo Osterkamp]] ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Bf 108A||11.48||86 pts |- |4.|| [[Jerzy Bajan]] ||{{POL}}|| RWD-9S   ||12.11||79 pts |- |5.|| [[Szczepan Grzeszczyk]]|| {{POL}}||PZL.26||12.26||78 pts |}
After further trials had been completed, on September 5 the leaders of a general classification changed and remained similar until the end of this part. Leaders were: Jerzy Bajan (RWD-9S, 875 pts), Tadeusz Karpiński (RWD-9S, 856 pts), [[Hans Seidemann]] (Fi 97, 850 pts), Gerhard Hubrich (Fi 97, 848 pts), Stanisław Płonczyński (RWD-9, 844 pts), then Karl Francke (Bf 108), Jan Buczyński (RWD-9), [[Wolf Hirth]] (Fi 97), Szczepan Grzeszczyk (PZL.26).
A minimal speed trial started on August 31, but it had to be continued on September 2 due to weather and some crews completed it only on September 6. The Pole [[Jerzy Bajan]] flying the [[RWD-9]] was the slowest with a speed of {{convert|54.14|kph|mph|abbr=on}}. Good results below 60 km/h were obtained by the other RWD-9s, the Czechoslovaks and the German Kl 36s and Fi 97s; the worst were Italian Bredas - above 75 km/h, what was not scored (a new device - slots in wings fitted in Bredas, proved useless in practice).
{| cellspacing=8 |- ! colspan=12|Top results of the minimal speed trial |- |   || Pilot || country || aircraft || speed ||points |- |1.||[[Jerzy Bajan]] ||{{POL}}|| RWD-9S||54.14 km/h||83 pts |- |2.||Jan Anderle ||{{CZS}}   || RWD-9W||55.24 km/h  ||79 pts |- |3.||[[Ján Ambruš]] ||{{CZS}}|| Aero A.200||55.88 km/h||76 pts |- |4.||Stanisław Płonczyński ||{{POL}}|| RWD-9S||56.72 km/h||73 pts |- |5.|| Wolfgang Stein ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Klemm Kl 36   ||57.67 km/h||69 pts |- |6.|| [[Fritz Morzik]]||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Klemm Kl 36||57.78 km/h||68 pts |}
[[Image:RWD 9 - Challenge1934.jpg|thumb|250px|Bajan's RWD-9 during a wing folding trial.]] On September 1 there was a trial of quick folding of wings, which was a feature to save space in hangars. Also the aircraft dimensions and the way of folding were awarded points. The trial was completed only on September 6, and first 7 results were of RWD-9s with 36 points, followed by four Italians.
One German and one Italian crews damaged their aircraft during technical trials (Bf 108 and PS-1) and had to retire. It was however the best ratio of crews to complete the technical trials of all Challenges. Generally, top places were taken by RWD-9s and Fi 97s, while Bf 108s, Kl 36s and PZL.26s proved average, and Italian machines closed a list with 559-801 points.
{| cellspacing=8 |- ! colspan=12|Top results after the technical trials |- |   || Pilot || Country || Aircraft || Points |- |1.|| [[Jerzy Bajan]] ||{{POL}}|| [[RWD-9]]S||- 994 pts |- |2.|| Tadeusz Karpiński|| {{POL}}||RWD-9S||- 954 pts |- |3.|| [[Stanisław Płonczyński]] ||{{POL}} || RWD-9S||- 953 pts |- |4.|| [[Hans Seidemann]] ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||[[Fieseler Fi 97]]||- 939 pts |- |5.|| Gerhard Hubrich ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Fieseler Fi 97||- 936 pts |- |6. ||Jan Buczyński ||{{POL}}|| RWD-9S|| - 920 pts |- |7. ||Stefan Florjanowicz ||{{POL}}|| RWD-9W|| - 919 pts |- |8-10.|| [[Wolf Hirth]] ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Fieseler Fi 97||- 915 pts |- |8-10.||[[Ján Ambruš]] ||{{CZS}}  || [[Aero A.200]]|| - 915 pts |- |8-10.||Jan Anderle ||{{CZS}}|| RWD-9W|| - 915 pts |}
==Rally over Europe== The second part of the Challenge was a 9537.4 km rally over Europe and northern Africa, on a path: [[Warsaw]] - [[Königsberg]] - [[Berlin]] - [[Köln]] - [[Brussels]] - [[Paris]] - [[Bordeaux]] - [[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]] - [[Madrid]] - [[Seville]] - [[Casablanca]] - [[Meknes]] - [[Sidi Bel Abbes]] - [[Algiers]] (stage waypoint) - [[Biskra]] - [[Tunis]] - [[Palermo]] - [[Naples]] - [[Rome]] - [[Rimini]] - [[Zagreb]] - [[Vienna]] - [[Brno]] - [[Prague]] - [[Katowice]] - [[Lwów]] - [[Wilno]] - Warsaw. There were also 8 checkpoints, among others, in [[Tanger]], [[Messina]] and [[Castelfranco Veneto]]. The route was far longer and more difficult, than in previous contests. Awarded were, first of all, a cruise speed on a whole track, then a regularity of flight. Three nights apart from appointed airfields or a cruise speed below 130 km/h caused disqualification.
The rally started on September 7, in rain, between 5 and 5.30 am. The Bf 108s could take advantage of their speed and were first to reach [[Berlin]]. That day 24 fastest crews reached [[Paris]], flying 1752.4 km (10 Poles, 8 Germans, 3 Czechoslovaks and 3 Italians). The German Wolfgang Stein (Kl 36) and the Italian team's captain [[Ambrogio Colombo]] (Ba-42) had to land and quit due to engine faults. Several crews had similar problems, but managed to repair them.
On the next day, many crews, who started early, especially flying Bf 108s, had problems with locating an airfield in [[Bordeaux]] due to heavy fog and had forced landings, lowering their cruise speed (on that occasion, [[Theo Osterkamp]] and Gerhard Hubrich had problems with the local police). One Klemm Kl 36 was damaged during a forced landing and had to withdraw (Ernst Krüger). Most - 14 crews reached [[Seville]] that day, 9 stayed in [[Madrid]], while last two crews remained in [[Bordeaux]], including Stanisław Płonczyński (RWD-9). Two Poles (Andrzej Włodarkiewicz and Szczepan Grzeszczyk on PZL.26s) reached as far, as [[Casablanca]] (3715.2 km).
On September 9 all crews, that remained in the rally, reached Africa, with Andrzej Włodarkiewicz and three Bf 108s being in the lead. 18 crews reached [[Algiers]] that day (9 Poles, 6 Germans and 3 Czechs), flying 4774 km in total. Last two crews reached [[Meknes]], including Stanisław Płonczyński. Several crews withdrew that day: [[Fritz Morzik]] (the winner of 1929 and 1930 Challenges, flying Kl 36) had three forced landings before Algiers due to a fuel pump fault, also Szczepan Grzeszczyk's PZL.26's engine failed and he had a forced landing before [[Sidi Bel Abbes]]. Other German Kraft Eberhard (Kl 36) withdrew in Spain due to wing damage, the Pole Tadeusz Karpiński (RWD-9) quit in Seville because of low cruise speed, and one Italian quit because of illness (Pierro de Angeli). On September 10 the rest reached Algiers, and thus 24 crews completed the first part of the rally. The Pole Stefan Florjanowicz (RWD-9) had to withdraw there due to engine fault.
The contestants left Algiers on September 11, after a rest, and 23 crews reached [[Tunis]] that day. On September 12, the crews left for [[Palermo]], over the [[Mediterranean Sea]]. The flight was secured by the Italian Navy and the French floatplanes. 22 crews reached [[Rome]] that day, one Italian pilot withdrew due to engine damage.
On September 13 the weather was bad, but all but two crews reached [[Prague]] (7924 km). The fastest that day was [[Theo Osterkamp]] (Bf 108), but other two Bf 108 pilots had forced landings near [[Trieste]] due to weather and spent night at [[Zagreb]], what lowered their cruise speed.
On September 14, sixteen crews finished in Warsaw, greeted by crowds, the first was the Pole Ignacy Giedgowd (PZL-26). Among them were five Poles, six Germans, three Czechoslovaks and two Italians. That day, the fastest Polish pilot Andrzej Włodarkiewicz (PZL-26) had to land near [[Tarnów]] before [[Lwów]] and withdrew due to engine fault, also Walter MacPherson (Puss Moth) dropped out for the same reason before Lwów.
On September 15 last three crews reached Warsaw ([[Werner Junck]] and Karl Francke flying Bf 108s and Piotr Dudziński flying PZL.26). The last to drop out was Jan Balcer (PZL.26) due to a compressor damage, before [[Wilno]]. Fritz Morzik (Kl 36), Tadeusz Karpiński (RWD-9) and Andrzej Włodarkiewicz (PZL.26) finished that day in Warsaw, after repairing their aircraft, flying off the contest.
Only 19 crews out of 32 completed the rally. The only team to finish complete was the Czechoslovak one; apart from their A.200s, only all Fieseler Fi 97s completed the contest. In spite of highest maximum cruise speeds, the results of fastest Bf 108s was hampered by low cruise speeds in other stages of the rally. Best results were obtained by pilots who managed to maintain a good cruise speed during the whole rally. All participants who completed the rally, scored maximal amount of 160 points for regularity, spending nights on appointed airfields only.
{| cellspacing=8 |- ! colspan=12|Top results of the race |- |   || Pilot || Country || Aircraft || Average speed|| Points |- |1.||Georg Pasewaldt ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}} ||[[Fieseler Fi 97]]  ||215.33 km/h|| - 880 pts |- |2.||Ignacy Giedgowd||{{POL}}||[[PZL.26]]||213.33 km/h|| - 880 pts |- |3.||[[Ján Ambruš]]||{{CZS}}  || [[Aero A.200]]||211.12 km/h|| - 880 pts |- |4.||Piotr Dudziński||{{POL}}||PZL.26||211.05 km/h|| - 880 pts |- |5.||[[Theo Osterkamp]] ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}} ||Bf 108||208.74 km/h|| - 875 pts |- |6.||[[Hans Seidemann]] ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Fieseler Fi 97||208.28 km/h|| - 874 pts |- |7.||Stanisław Płonczyński||{{POL}}||[[RWD-9]]||206.89 km/h|| - 868 pts |- |8.||[[Jerzy Bajan]]||{{POL}}||RWD-9||205.15 km/h|| - 861 pts |- |9.||Jan Anderle||{{CZS}}|| RWD-9||203.69 km/h|| - 855 pts |- |10.||Kurt Bayer ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Fieseler Fi 97||203.47 km/h|| - 854 pts |}
After the technical trials and the race, Jerzy Bajan held first place in the general classification with 1855 points, with Stanisław Płonczyński in second with 1821 pts, Hans Seidemann in third with 1813 pts, followed by two Czechoslovaks, Slovak [[Ján Ambruš]] (1795 pts) and Czech Jan Anderle (1770 pts). Bf 108 pilots were 12th ([[Werner Junck]] - 1733 pts), 13th ([[Theo Osterkamp]] - 1729 pts) and 15th (Karl Francke - 1715 pts).
==Maximum speed trial== The last part of the Challenge was a maximum speed trial, on a 297 km triangular course. The trial was carried out on Sunday, September 16, from 4 pm, at the Mokotowskie airfield in Warsaw.
Due to a [[handicapping]] system, contestants took off in order of general classification, with proper intervals, and an amount of points given in the speed trial meant, that the first on the finishing line would be the winner of the contest. Each km/h above 210 km/h was awarded with one point.
The fastest were three German Bf 108s, with Theo Osterkamp at the lead (291 km/h). Next three places were taken by the Polish RWD-9s: Stanisław Płonczyński, Jan Buczyński, Jerzy Bajan and Henryk Skrzypiński, the later ex eaquo with Hans Seidemann (Fi 97). The Pole Ignacy Giedgowd (PZL.26) and the Italian Ernesto Sanzin (Ba-39S) had to land due to engine faults and scored 0 points.
{| cellspacing=8 |- ! colspan=12|Maximum speed trial |- |   || Pilot || Country || Aircraft || Speed || Points |- |1.||[[Theo Osterkamp]] ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}  ||Bf 108A||291 km/h  ||81 pts |- |2.||Karl Francke ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}} ||Bf 108A||287 km/h||77 pts |- |3.||[[Werner Junck]] ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Bf 108A||283 km/h||73 pts |- |4.||Stanisław Płonczyński||{{POL}}||RWD-9S||255 km/h|| 45 pts |- |5.||Jan Buczyński ||{{POL}}|| RWD-9S ||254 km/h||44 pts |- |6.|| [[Jerzy Bajan]] ||{{POL}}|| RWD-9S ||251 km/h||41 pts |- |7/8.|| Henryk Skrzypiński ||{{POL}}|| RWD-9W ||243 km/h||33 pts |- |7/8.||[[Hans Seidemann]] ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Fieseler Fi 97||243 km/h|| 33 pts |- |9.||Piotr Dudziński||{{POL}}||PZL.26||241 km/h|| 31 pts |- |10/11.||Gerhard Hubrich ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Fieseler Fi 97  ||239 km/h|| 29 pts |- |10/11.||Georg Pasewaldt ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Fieseler Fi 97||239 km/h|| 29 pts |- |12/14.||Wolf Hirth ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Fieseler Fi 97||237 km/h|| 27 pts |- |12/14.||[[Ján Ambruš]]||{{CZS}}  || Aero A.200||237 km/h|| 27 pts |- |12/14.||Jan Anderle||{{CZS}} || RWD-9W||237 km/h|| 27 pts |- |15.||Kurt Bayer ||{{flag|Nazi Germany}}||Fieseler Fi 97||236 km/h|| 26 pts |- |16.||Vojtěch Žáček ||{{CZS}}|| Aero A.200||224 km/h|| 14 pts |- |17.||Armando François||{{flag|Italy|1861}}|| PS-1||223 km/h|| 13 pts |}
Bf 108s managed to improve their positions, but first four places in general classification have not changed. The first contestants arrived in order: Bajan - Płonczyński - Seidemann - Ambruz - Osterkamp - Junck.
==Results== [[File:Bajan-Pilsudski-Pokrzywka.jpg|thumb|220px|Polish aviators - winners of Challenge 1934: pilot Jerzy Bajan (left) and mechanic Gustaw Pokrzywka (right) with Marshal [[Józef Piłsudski]] (center).]] A closing ceremony was held soon after the maximum speed test on September 16. The winners were the Polish crew of pilot [[Jerzy Bajan]] and mechanic Gustaw Pokrzywka. Their success was not only a result of their aviation skills, but also of the technical features of their Polish-designed [[RWD-9]]. Due to their victory, Poland had a right to organize the next Challenge in 1936, but it decided not to, because of financial reasons. The FAI proposed that other countries organize the contest, but Germany, Italy and France declined. The 1934 Challenge remained the last Challenge and the [[Polish Aero Club]] was given a right to retain a transitory cup.

{{Infobox stadium | name = DNB Arena | nickname = | logo_image = [[File:Dnbarenalogo.jpeg|150px]] | image = DNB Arena.JPG | image_size = 300px | caption = | fullname = | location = [[Madla]], [[Stavanger]], [[Norway]] | coordinates = {{coord|58.954|5.693|type:landmark_region:NO|format=dms|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 7 October 2012 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Stavanger Oilers]] | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = {{NOK|210 million}} | architect = Arkitektkontoret Jobb | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = Kruse Smith | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Stavanger Oilers]] (2012-present)
[[2013 IIHF Women's World Championship Division I]] | capacity = 4,377 (ice hockey)
6,000 (concerts) | dimensions = | scoreboard = | publictransit = '''Bus''': Line 2, 3, 6, 7, 16, N84, N86, X73 }} '''DNB Arena''' is an indoor [[ice hockey rink]] in [[Stavanger]], [[Norway]], and home to the [[GET-ligaen]] side [[Stavanger Oilers]]. Opened ahead of the [[2012–13 GET-ligaen season|2012–13 season]], the [[arena]] has a capacity for 4,500 spectators during [[ice hockey]] matches and 6,000 during concerts, including 36 [[executive boxes]]. The rink is unusual for Norway in that it has the [[National Hockey League]] rink size. The {{convert|16500|m2|sp=us}} building is designed by Arkitektkontoret Jobb and is named for [[DNB ASA|DNB]], a Norwegian banking group. Plans for a new venue to replace the aging [[Stavanger Ishall]] were first articulated by club-owner Tore Christiansen in 2006. Construction started in May 2011, with Kruse Smith as the main contractor. Construction cost 210 million [[Norwegian krone]] (NOK). The venue is owned by the Oilers' investment company, which receives a combined 9 million per year from DNB and the municipality. The arena hosted group stages of [[2012–13 IIHF Continental Cup]] and [[2013 IIHF Women's World Championship Division I]]. ==Construction== Plans for a new arena for the Stavanger Oilers was first articulated by club-owner and chairman Tore Christiansen in 2006.{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article2418546.ece |title=– Oilershall i 2009 |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Svendsen |first=Torbjørn |date=17 November 2006 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BF6YwAmY?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article2418546.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} By 2007 the Oilers had the highest attendance of any team in the GET-Ligaen, when they reached an average 2,000. The club stated that additional increase would be difficult, especially because seats were all sold to season ticket holders and that terrace spaces were only being sold to top matches.{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article2540969.ece |title=Oilers har flest tilskuere |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Iversen |first=Espen |date=24 January 2007 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BF6suZ8G?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article2540969.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} The city council passed the zoning plan for the arena area on 19 October 2009.{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article4653206.ece |title=Oilers Arena fikk ja |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Fisketjøn |first=Lars |date=19 October 2009 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BF1Ew1QH?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article4653206.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} However, construction start was delayed after a disagreement arose between the municipality and the arena company regarding the use of commercial areas.{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article4843285.ece |title=Kan miste investorer |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Fisketjøn |first=Lars |date=4 February 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BF1X9goB?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article4843285.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} Part of the financing comes from NOK 4 million per year over 20 years paid by the municipality for ice time for local clubs.{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/meninger/kommentar/article5627932.ece |title=Skolekutt med konsekvenser |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Molina |first=Marcela Tvedt |date=4 June 2011 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BF6OwJPk?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/meninger/kommentar/article5627932.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} Construction commenced on 13 May 2011 with Kruse Smith as the main contractor.{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article5604617.ece |title=Første spadetak for Oilers Arena |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Fadnes |first=Jon Kristian |date=13 May 2011 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BF49pTZy?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article5604617.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} The project was originally named Oilers Arena, but in September 2011 the club signed a ten-year agreement with DNB for the naming rights, worth NOK 5 million per year.{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article5736334.ece |title=Storbank vil sponse Oilers Arena |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |date=14 September 2009 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BF4YzJ1f?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article5736334.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} The building made of prefabricated elements manufactured by Spenncon.{{cite web|url=http://spenncon.no/spenncon/referanser/naringsbygg/idrettsanlegg/ |title=DNB Arena (Oilers Ishockey Stadion) |publisher=Spenncon |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BF5vzEOY?url=http://spenncon.no/spenncon/referanser/naringsbygg/idrettsanlegg/ |deadurl=no |df= }} Construction cost NOK 210 million. Ahead of the 2012–13 season, the Oilers sold 3,000 season tickets.{{cite news|url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/rogaland/nord-jaeren/1.8315749 |title=– Det er noe av det vakreste jeg har sett |publisher=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |last=Friestad |first=Mari |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BF7PJqpl?url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/rogaland/nord-jaeren/1.8315749 |deadurl=no |df= }} The arena was inaugurated with an Oilers training session on 1 October.{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article6262788.ece |title=Nå er de igang |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Fisketjøn |first=Lars |date=1 October 2012 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BEwrQbBD?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article6262788.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} Stavanger Municipal Council gave, against the votes of the [[Christian Democratic Party (Norway)|Christian Democratic Party]] and the [[Socialist Left Party (Norway)|Socialist Left Party]], a temporary permission to serve alcoholic beverages at matches. The team stated that they hoped this would pave the way for alcohol service at other sports events in the country.{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article6268655.ece |title=Oilers fikk øl-ja |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Ellingsen |first=Øyvind |date=1 October 2012 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BEzODwem?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article6268655.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} The first match took place on 7 October, with Oilers beating 3–2.{{cite news |url=http://sport.aftenposten.no/sport/ishockey/article252966.ece |title=Shampo tror på ny arena innen tre år |work=[[Aftenposten]] |last=Røed-Johansen |first=Daniel |date=7 October 2011 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010000831/http://sport.aftenposten.no/sport/ishockey/article252966.ece |archivedate=10 October 2012 |df= }} ==Facilities== DNB Arena is located at Madlaveien, next to the Oilers' old venue [[Stavanger Ishall]] (also known as Siddishallen). The area has a capacity for 4,500 spectators during ice hockey matches and 6,000 during concerts, including 36 executive boxes. The rink measures {{convert|26|by|60|m}}, the standard for the [[National Hockey League]] and narrower than the standard of the [[International Ice Hockey Federation]], which is normally used in Norway. The structure has a floor area of {{convert|16500|m2|sp=us}} and was designed by Arkitektkontoret Jobb. It is named for DNB, a Norwegian banking group.{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article5803644.ece |title=Dette skal hallen hete |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Espedal |first=Tore |date=11 November 2011 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BEuQ7RUQ?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article5803644.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} Seats are softened with textiles and the club has chosen to not color the venue in their team colors to keep focus on the playing field and make it easier for the venue to be used for other events. The sound system cost NOK 8 million and was delivered by [[Bose Corporation|Bose]] and [[Electrocompaniet]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article6242726.ece |title=Oilers sier nei til kontanter i DNB Arena |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Fisketjøn |first=Lars |date=18 September 2012 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BEmti84k?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article6242726.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} The concessionaires do not accept cash; only cards and prepaid cashless systems are accepted.{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article6265871.ece |title=– Har ikke gått i luksusfellen |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Iversen |first=Espen |date=3 October 2012 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BEyuPd6Z?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article6265871.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} ==Events== Oilers hosted Group E of the [[2012–13 IIHF Continental Cup]]. Played between 23 and 25 November, the group was contested between Oilers, Belarus' [[Metallurg Zhlobin]], Poland's [[KH Sanok]] and the winner of Group C, [[Beibarys Atyrau]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article6120725.ece |title=Fikset europacup |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Fisketjøn |first=Lars |date=24 June 2012 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BEwg9MUp?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/oilers/article6120725.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} The venue is scheduled to host Group A of the [[2013 IIHF Women's World Championship Division I]] between 7 and 14 April. In addition to [[Norway women's national ice hockey team|Norway]], the tournament will feature [[Austria women's national ice hockey team|Austria]], [[Denmark women's national ice hockey team|Denmark]], [[Japan women's national ice hockey team|Japan]], [[Latvia women's national ice hockey team|Latvia]] and [[Slovakia women's national ice hockey team|Slovakia]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/article6066155.ece |title=Stavanger får hockey-VM for kvinner |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Birkemo |first=Arne |date=5 May 2012 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BEufoslr?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/sport/article6066155.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} Scheduled concerts are [[Brad Paisley]] on 11 November 2012{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/puls/article6113111.ece |title=Brad Paisley til DNB Arena |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Fadnes |first=Jon Kristian |date=19 June 2012 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BEwC2PYf?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/puls/article6113111.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} and [[Mark Knopfler]] on 13 June 2013.{{cite news|url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/puls/article6221181.ece |title=Konserten utsolgt allerede |work=[[Rogalands Avis]] |last=Fossmo |first=Stein Roger |date=5 September 2012 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=7 October 2012 |archivedate=7 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BEuIxuKX?url=http://www.rogalandsavis.no/puls/article6221181.ece |deadurl=no |df= }} The venue will along with other halls be used to host future [[Offshore Northern Seas]] trade fairs. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{GET-ligaen}} {{commons category|DNB Arena (Stavanger)}} [[Category:Stavanger Oilers]] [[Category:Sports venues in Stavanger]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Norway]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Norway]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2012]] [[Category:2012 establishments in Norway]]

{{Infobox information appliance | name = DUBS Acoustic Filters | logo = | image = Getdubs-case-tint.jpg | image_size = | developer = Doppler Labs | manufacturer = | family = | type = [[Wireless]] [[Headphones#Earphones|earbuds]] | release date = 2014 | units sold = | website = [https://www.getdubs.com/ Get Dubs] }} '''DUBS Acoustic Filters''' are high-tech ear plugs designed by [[Doppler Labs]] and released in 2014. They use a proprietary 17-piece physical acoustic filter system to reduce sound pressure at different frequencies while maintaining acoustical fidelity.<ref name="Gizmodo '14">{{cite web|last1=Aguilar|first1=Mario|title=Dubs Earplugs Don't Look Terrible So You Might Actually Wear Them|url=https://gizmodo.com/dubs-earplugs-dont-look-terrible-so-you-might-actually-1638017710|website=Gizmodo|accessdate=1 December 2017}}</ref><ref name="TechCrunch">{{cite web|last1=Crook|first1=Jordan|title=Meet Dubs, Doppler Labs’ Reinvention Of The Lowly Earplug|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/09/23/meet-dubs-doppler-labs-reinvention-of-the-lowly-earplug/|website=TechCrunch|accessdate=1 December 2017|language=en}}</ref>
==History== In 2014, Doppler Labs launched DUBS Acoustic Filters as their first product at the [[Global Citizen Festival]] in [[New York City]].<ref name="Yahoo">{{cite web|title=Protect your ears and still enjoy the music with Dubs earplugs|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/protect-ears-still-enjoy-music-dubs-earplugs-184151431.html|website=Yahoo|accessdate=1 December 2017}}</ref> In 2015, Doppler Labs announced a partnership<ref name="Instagram">{{cite web|title=Instagram post by Coachella • Feb 24, 2015 at 9:03pm UTC|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/zf5JrXEshk/|website=Instagram|accessdate=1 December 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref name="Billboard">{{cite web|last1=Hampp|first1=Andrew|title=Doppler Labs' DUBS to Become Official Earplug of Bonnaroo, Outside Lands|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/music-festivals/6546160/doppler-labs-dubs-earplug-bonnaroo-outside-lands|website=Billboard|accessdate=1 December 2017}}</ref> with [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival|Coachella Music and Arts Festival]] promoter [[Goldenvoice]] to distribute more than 130,000 pairs of DUBS to festival attendees through the official Coachella welcome box.<ref name="WSJ">{{cite web|last1=Karp|first1=Hannah|title=Earplugs, a New Dance-Fest Must-Have?|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/earplugs-a-new-dance-fest-must-have-1424738680|website=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=1 December 2017|date=24 February 2015}}</ref>
Doppler Labs brought on a roster of partners and investors from the entertainment and music industries to support DUBS including [[Hans Zimmer]],<ref name="Wareable">{{cite web|last1=Charara|first1=Sophie|title=Coachella is getting stages optimised for Here active listening earbuds|url=https://www.wareable.com/hearables/coachella-festival-here-active-listening-earbuds-2174|website=Wareable|accessdate=1 December 2017|language=en}}</ref> [[Quincy Jones]], [[Tiesto]], and [[Mark Ronson]], among others.<ref name="Thump">{{cite web|last1=Garber|first1=David|title=Doppler Labs' New Bluetooth Earbuds Are Like a Remote Control For Your Ears|url=https://thump.vice.com/en_us/article/kb5wxm/doppler-labs-new-bluetooth-earbuds-are-like-a-remote-control-for-your-ears|website=Thump|accessdate=1 December 2017|language=en-us|date=10 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="digital trends">{{cite web|last1=Olewitz|first1=Chloe|title=Coachella attendees will get early access to Doppler Labs’ sound-tweaking ‘Here’ earbuds|url=https://www.digitaltrends.com/cool-tech/coachella-exclusive-access-here-active-listening/|website=Digital Trends|accessdate=1 December 2017|date=14 January 2016}}</ref>
==Design== Doppler Labs designed DUBS Acoustic Filters to accommodate the need for audio fidelity when listening to music.<ref name="Fast Company">{{cite web|last1=McCracken|first1=Harry|title=Doppler Labs And The Quest To Build A Computer For Your Ears|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3062996/doppler-labs-and-the-quest-to-build-a-computer-for-your-ears|website=Fast Company|accessdate=1 December 2017|date=21 September 2016}}</ref><ref name="Your EDM">{{cite web|last1=Rubinstein|first1=Peter|title=Coachella Including Free Earplugs With Ticket {{!}} Your EDM|url=http://www.youredm.com/2015/02/26/coachella-including-free-earplugs-ticket/|website=Your EDM|accessdate=1 December 2017|date=26 February 2015}}</ref> In 2015, DUBS were awarded the [[Red Dot|Red Dot Award]] in [[Product Design]] for their "organic design" and "sophisticated technology".<ref name="Red Dot">{{cite web|title=DUBS Acoustic Filters - 2015 work Red Dot Award: Product Design|url=https://red-dot.de/pd/online-exhibition/work/?lang=en&code=13-05110-2015&y=2015&c=170&a=0|website=red-dot.de|accessdate=1 December 2017}}</ref><ref name="Wired">{{cite web|last1=Pierce|first1=David|title=These Sci-Fi Earbuds Put a Volume Knob on the Real World|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/06/doppler-here/|website=WIRED|accessdate=1 December 2017}}</ref>
==Reception== DUBS Acoustic Filters were widely reviewed by media for their ability to protect people’s hearing at concerts without sacrificing the fidelity of the music<ref>{{cite web|last1=Crook|first1=Jordan|title=DUBS Bring Down The Noise In Night Clubs|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/12/05/dubs-bring-down-the-noise-in-night-clubs/?ncid=rss|website=TechCrunch|accessdate=1 December 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref name="Technogog">{{cite web|last1=Ratas|first1=Tomas|title=Review of DUBS Acoustic Filters {{!}} Technogog|url=https://technogog.com/review/review-of-dubs-acoustic-filters/|website=technogog.com|accessdate=1 December 2017}}</ref><ref name="GearDiary">{{cite web|last1=Cohen|first1=Dan|title=DUBS Acoustic Filters Protect Your Ears and the Quality of the Sound|url=https://geardiary.com/2014/11/30/dubs-acoustic-filters-protect-your-ears-and-the-quality-of-the-sound/|website=GearDiary|accessdate=1 December 2017|date=30 November 2014}}</ref> and as suitable accessories for air travel.<ref name="Entrepreneur">{{cite web|last1=Cipriani|first1=Jason|title=5 Ways to Hack Your Holiday Travel|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/239896|website=Entrepreneur|accessdate=1 December 2017|language=en|date=18 November 2014}}</ref>

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Estadio Nacional Julio Martínez Prádanos | nickname = El Nacional, El Coloso de Ñuñoa | image = [[File:Estadio Nacional de Chile - vista desde Av. Grecia.jpg|300px]] | caption = | location = Av. Grecia 2001, [[Ñuñoa]], [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]], [[Chile]] | coordinates = {{coord|33|27|52|S|70|36|38|W}} | broke_ground = February 1937 | opened = December 3, 1938 | expanded = 1962 | renovated = 2009–10 | reopened = 12 September 2010 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Municipality of [[Ñuñoa]] | operator = Chiledeportes | surface = Grass | construction_cost = $18,000,000 | architect =Karl Brunner | project_manager = | main_contractors = | publictransit = [[File:Santiago Metro logo.png|20px|link=Santiago Metro]] [[File:Santiago de Chile L6.svg|20px|link=Santiago Metro Line 6]] at [[Estadio Nacional metro station|Estadio Nacional]] | former_names = Estadio Nacional (1938–2008) | tenants = [[Chile national football team]]
[[Club Universidad de Chile|Universidad de Chile]] | seating_capacity = 48,665{{cite web|url=http://www.conmebol.com/es/copa-america-2015/sedes|title=Copa América 2015|work=conmebol.com}} (60.000+ in concerts) | record_attendance = {{formatnum: 85268}} ([[Club Universidad de Chile|Universidad de Chile]]–[[Club Deportivo Universidad Católica|Universidad Católica]], 29 December 1962) | dimensions = 105 m x 68 m }} '''Estadio Nacional Julio Martínez Prádanos''' (originally known as '''Estadio Nacional de Chile''') is the [[national stadium]] of [[Chile]], and is located in the [[Ñuñoa]] district of [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]]. It is the largest stadium in Chile with an official capacity of 48,665. It is part of a 62 [[hectare]] sporting complex which also features [[tennis court]]s, an aquatics center, a modern [[gym]]nasium, a velodrome, a BMX circuit, and an assistant ground/warmup athletics track. Construction began in February 1937 and the stadium was inaugurated on December 3, 1938. The [[architecture]] was based on the [[Olympic Stadium (Berlin)|Olympiastadion]] in [[Berlin]], [[Germany]]. The stadium was one of the venues for the [[1962 FIFA World Cup|FIFA World Cup in 1962]], and hosted [[1962 FIFA World Cup Final|the final]] where [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] defeated [[Czechoslovakia national football team|Czechoslovakia]] 3-1. In 1948, the stadium hosted the matches of the [[South American Championship of Champions]], the competition that inspired the creation of the [[UEFA Champions League]][http://globotv.globo.com/globocom/liga-dos-campeoes-da-uefa/v/especial-liga-dos-campeoes-completa-60-anos-e-neymar-ajuda-a-contar-essa-historia/4168641/ ''Globo Esporte'' TV Programme, Brazil, May 10, 2015: ''Especial: Liga dos Campeões completa 60 anos, e Neymar ajuda a contar essa história''. Accessed on December 6th 2015. In this interview to the Brazilian sports TV programme Globo Esporte, Jacques Ferran (the creator of the European Champions Cup) states that the South American Championship of Champions was his inspiration for the creation of the European continental competition. Ferran's speech goes from 5:02 to 6:51 in the video.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304052701/http://globotv.globo.com/globocom/liga-dos-campeoes-da-uefa/v/especial-liga-dos-campeoes-completa-60-anos-e-neymar-ajuda-a-contar-essa-historia/4168641/ |date=2016-03-04 }} and of the [[Copa Libertadores]].{{cite web|url=http://www.conmebol.com/es/historia-copa-libertadores|title=Copa Libertadores. Historia |publisher= CONMEBOL|website=www.conmebol.com}} The stadium was notoriously used as a [[internment|prison camp]] and torture facility by the military regime following the [[Chilean coup d'état]]. In 2009, a complete modernization plan was unveiled for the stadium and surrounding facilities. President [[Michelle Bachelet]] said it would become the most modern stadium in South America.{{cite web|url=http://papeldigital.info/lt/|title=Estadio Nacional costará US$ 42 millones y la "Roja" se va al Monumental|work=[[La Tercera]]|date=2009-06-16|accessdate=2009-06-16|language=Spanish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090611190808/http://papeldigital.info/lt/|archivedate=2009-06-11|df=}} The stadium will be the Opening and Closing ceremonies, athletics and football venue for the [[2023 Pan American Games]]. [[File:180° Panorama Estadio Nacional Santiago Chile.jpg|right|300px]] ==History== The stadium was built on former farmland, donated in 1918 by farmer Jose Domingo Cañas. The first sporting event in the new stadium took place on 3 December 1938, with a friendly game between the Chilean club [[Colo-Colo]] and Brazilian club [[São Cristóvão]]. Colo-Colo won 6–3. It has hosted all matches of the [[1941 South American Championship|1941]], [[1945 South American Championship|1945]] and [[1955 South American Championship|1955]] South American Football Championships, and several matches of the [[1991 Copa América|1991]] and [[2015 Copa América|2015]] [[Copa América]]. The stadium hosted the final stages of the [[1959 FIBA World Championship|1959 World Basketball Championship]]. It was held outdoors because the intended venue, the [[Movistar Arena|Metropolitan Indoor Stadium]], was not ready in time. In the early 1960s, under the government of [[Jorge Alessandri]], the stadium was expanded to host the [[1962 FIFA World Cup]]. The main change was that the velodrome that surrounded the stadium was replaced by galleries, thereby increasing its original capacity to around 95,000. The stadium hosted group stage games between [[Italy]], [[West Germany]], [[Switzerland]] and Chile, including a notoriously ill-tempered and violent clash between Italy and Chile which became known as the [[Battle of Santiago (1962 FIFA World Cup)|Battle of Santiago]]. Also held at the ground were a quarter-final, a semi-final, the third place play-off, and the final, in which Brazil was crowned world champions for the second time. In the third-place play-off, Chile defeated Yugoslavia 1–0, marking the team's greatest success in international football. Today, the ground serves as the home field for both the national team and the first-division club [[Universidad de Chile (football club)|Universidad de Chile]]. It also hosts non-sporting events, such as political celebrations, charity events and concerts. The stadium has been used since 1995 as the final leg of the [[Teletón (Chile)|Telethon]], a 28-hour telecast. The stadium holds up to 100,000 people for this annual event with the Jumbotron showing the required amount to reach the goal and its current total. On July 5, 2008, the stadium was officially renamed ''Estadio Nacional [[Julio Martínez Prádanos]]'', in honor of a recently deceased sports journalist.{{cite web|url=http://www.bcn.cl/actualidad_legislativa/estadio-julio-martinez-pradanos |title=Publicada Ley que denomina Julio Martínez al Estadio Nacional de Santiago – Biblioteca del Congreso Nacional de Chile |language=es |publisher=Bcn.cl |date= |accessdate=2011-06-03}} ===Use as a detention center=== [[File:Chile- el pueblo vencera cropped.jpg|thumb|300px|Estadio Nacional de Chile after the [[1973 Chilean coup d'état]].]] After the [[1973 Chilean coup d'état|coup d'état]] of September 11, 1973 that ousted President Salvador Allende, the stadium began to be used as a detention facility. An article in the ''Harvard Review of Latin America'' reported that "there were over eighty detention centers in Santiago alone" and gave details of the National Stadium and others.{{cite web|url=http://www.drclas.harvard.edu/revista/articles/view/704 |title=Harvard Review of Latin America: Chile's National Stadium, with details on several detention centers |publisher=Drclas.harvard.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-06-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811054833/http://www.drclas.harvard.edu/revista/articles/view/704 |archivedate=August 11, 2011 }} Over 40,000 people spent time in the compound during the ''junta'' regime. Twelve thousand detainees were interned between September 11 and November 7.{{cite web|url=http://www.consejodelacultura.cl/chileaudiovisual1/pag/pc-documentales.html |title= Chile Audio Visual |publisher=Consejodelacultura.cl |date= |accessdate=2011-06-03}} The field and gallery were used to hold men, while women were held in the [[swimming pool]] changing rooms and associated buildings. Locker rooms and corridors were all used as prison facilities while interrogations were carried out in the [[velodrome]].Carmen Luz Parot, 2002, ''Estadio Nacional. Documental'' (''National Stadium Documentary''). Produced by ''Sello Alerce'', Chile, 2002. The Red Cross estimated that 7,000 prisoners occupied the stadium at one point, of whom about 300 were foreigners. According to the testimonies of survivors collected by the humanitarian group, detainees were tortured and threatened with death by shooting. Some were shot on the premises and then taken to unknown locations for execution. [[FIFA]] President [[Stanley Rous|Sir Stanley Rous]] insisted the [[USSR national football team|USSR team]] to play [[1974 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA–CONMEBOL play-off)|a World Cup qualifier]] at the time. They however refused to do so and [[Chile national football team|Chile]] qualified automatically for the [[1974 FIFA World Cup|1974 World Cup]], where they failed to advance from a group containing both [[German national football team|West]] and [[East Germany national football team|East Germany]] and [[Australia national football team|Australia]]. The use of the stadium during the coup d'état is depicted in the 2002 [[documentary film]] ''Estadio Nacional'', directed and produced by [[Carmen Luz Parot]], and in the 2007 Swedish film ''[[The Black Pimpernel]]'', which is based on the story of Swedish ambassador in Chile [[Harald Edelstam]] and his heroic actions to protect the lives of over 1,200 people during and after the military coup. ''The Black Pimpernel'' was shot on location in Santiago. The 1982 film ''[[Missing (1982 film)|Missing]]'' by Greek filmmaker [[Costa-Gavras]] depicts the September 11, 1973 coup d'état and execution of American journalists [[Charles Horman]] and [[Frank Teruggi]] at the Estadio Nacional. In 2011, Chile set aside a section of the stadium, a section of old wooden bleachers called [[:es:Escotilla n.º 8|"Escotilla 8"]], to honor the prisoners who were detained there.{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/off-the-field/the-soccer-match-that-should-have-never-been-played-8679e8d91191 |title= The Soccer Match That Should Have Never Been Played |publisher=medium.com |date= |accessdate=2017-11-29}} ===2009–2010 renovation=== [[File:Adios Matador.jpg|thumb|[[Marcelo Salas]] farewell match, June 2, 2009]] On June 15, 2009, President [[Michelle Bachelet]] announced several infrastructure improvements in order to modernize the stadium and its immediate facilities. Out of the total 24 billion [[Chilean peso|pesos]] (US$42.3 million) contemplated in the plan, 20 billion pesos (US$35.3 million) are destined to bring the stadium up to modern standards. The changes include, a roof covering all the seats, which will also provide illumination; installation of seats around the entire stadium, lowering the current capacity to 47,000; a new state-of-the-art [[scoreboard]]; a 2.5 m deep 2 m wide pit will separate the track and the spectators to replace the fence; and several other changes. Because the stadium is a [[National Monuments of Chile|national monument]] the façade will remain the same, with the roof structure placed on top, without modifying the exterior. The stadium was closed on August 15, 2009. The stadium was scheduled to be reinaugurated in March 2010 to stage a double friendly match between Chile and [[North Korea]] and [[Panama]], but the works were not finished on time. The construction of the roof has since been postponed by the government of President [[Sebastián Piñera]] due to financial constraints brought about by the [[2010 Chile earthquake|February 27, 2010 earthquake]]. Although the stadium suffered minor damage from the earthquake, it partially opened to host the match between [[Universidad de Chile (football club)|C.F. Universidad de Chile]] and [[C.D. Guadalajara]] for [[2010 Copa Libertadores|Copa Libertadores 2010]]. It was officially re-inaugurated on September 12, 2010, during Chile's bicentennial festivities. ===2014 South American Games renovation=== On September 12, 2010, during the Chilean bicentennial festivities, President [[Sebastián Piñera]] announced that the capacity of the stadium will be increased so as to reach 70,000 seats for the [[2014 South American Games]] that will take place in Santiago.{{cite web|url=http://diario.latercera.com/2010/09/13/01/contenido/deportes/4-38522-9-el-nacional-sera-para-70-mil-personas.shtml |title=La Tercera Edición Impresa |publisher=Diario.latercera.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-03}} The works are expected to begin in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://diario.latercera.com/2010/09/19/01/contenido/deportes/4-39062-9-el-actual-nacional-no-es-negocio-para-la-seleccion.shtml |title=La Tercera Edición Impresa |publisher=Diario.latercera.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-03}} On June 3, 2011 further renovation plans were announced by the government. The complete area surrounding the stadium will be turned into a park to be called "Citizenry Park" (''Parque de la Ciudadanía''). Over 70% of the new 64-hectare park will consist of green areas, and the rest will include new infrastructure such as a lagoon or restaurants. The new park is expected to be ready for the 2014 games. New sporting venues will be built for the 2014 games, such as two modern gymnasiums, a new heated pool for [[synchronized swimming]], a renovated velodrome and an expanded CAR, which will also serve as residence of the future Ministry of Sports. The only venues that will remain are the stadium, the main tennis court, the velodrome, the CAR, the athletics track, the skating track, the hockey field and the ''caracolas''.{{cite web|url=http://diario.latercera.com/2011/06/03/01/contenido/santiago/32-71340-9-parque-del-estadio-nacional-tendra-una-laguna-restaurantes-y-cafes.shtml |title=Parque del Estadio Nacional tendrá una laguna, restaurantes y cafés | Santiago | La Tercera Edición Impresa |publisher=Diario.latercera.com |date=1990-01-01 |accessdate=2011-06-03}} ==Attendances== The highest attendance for a match at Estadio Nacional to date is 85,268, for a [[Liga Chilena de Fútbol: Primera División|Primera Division]] match played on December 29, 1962; [[Universidad de Chile (football club)|Universidad de Chile]] defeated [[Club Deportivo Universidad Católica|Universidad Catolica]] 4–1.{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} In the 2016–17 season, [[Universidad de Chile]] drew an average home league attendance of 30,041 for the Apertura and 33,466 for the Clausura.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldfootball.net/attendance/chi-primera-division-2016-2017-clausura/1/|title=Primera División 2016/2017 Clausura – Attendance|website=worldfootball.net}} ==Concerts== The stadium hosts many international, and two national ([[Los Prisioneros]]), concerts during the year. [[Rod Stewart]] was the first international artist to perform at the stadium. The concert brought more than 200,000 fans to the venue and was broadcast throughout the country. After that, the city started being included in many tours from international artists. The Following is a list of concerts, showing date, artist or band, tour, opening acts and attendance. He was also set to perform on October 21 but the show was cancelled due to health problems. * Both shows of [[Los Prisioneros]] in 2001 were released on cassette and CD as ''Estadio Nacional'', on VHS and DVD as ''Lo Estamos Pasando Muy Bien''. * During [[The Final Frontier World Tour]], [[Iron Maiden]] performed to an audience of over 40,000 at the stadium on 10 April 2011, while the press lists the attendance on over 60,000.{{cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4H0Ce4Wk3U4 | title = Iron Maiden En Chile, 60.000 aficionados disfrutaron del espectáculo | accessdate = 2012-04-22}} The show was recorded and released on CD, LP, DVD and Blu-ray as ''[[En Vivo! (Iron Maiden album)|En Vivo!]]'' in March 2012.{{cite web | url = http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=168388 | title = Iron Maiden To Release 'En Vivo!' Concert Blu-Ray, Two-DVD Set And Double Soundtrack Album | accessdate = 2012-01-17 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == Capacity == The stadium was built with an original capacity of 48,000 spectators in 1937. At the time, some considered it a "[[white elephant]]" because it was thought that it could never be filled. The term also alluded to the charges of corruption against the administration of Arturo Alessandri, which oversaw the stadium's costly construction.Brenda Elsey, Citizens and Sportsmen: Futbol and Politics in Twentieth Century Chile (Austin: University of Texas Press, 2011) For the [[1962 FIFA World Cup]], seating capacity was increased to 74,000 with overflow areas allowing for a total of more than 80,000 people, by eliminating the cycling track that was moved to another location. Over the years, seating capacity was reduced to keep escape routes clear and prevent accidents. For the [[2000 World Junior Championships in Athletics]], the installation of individual seats was required, which reduced capacity to 66,000 spectators. This requirement ensured that the stadium could not exceed capacity, as seen with the visit of [[Pope John Paul II]] in 1987 (believed to be attended by more than 90,000 people, though no accurate measurement could be taken as attendance was free, with no control), or the closing of the Telethon. The official capacity of the stadium as of 2014 is 48,665.{{cite web|url=http://www.stadiumguide.com/nacionaldechile/|title=Estadio Nacional de Chile|work=The Stadium Guide|accessdate=31 July 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Estadio Nacional de Chile}} *[http://www.fussballtempel.net/conmebol/CHL.html Football Temples of the World-Chile] *[http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/south_america/chile/santiago_nacional.shtml World Stadium Article] *[http://www.stadiumguide.com/nacionaldechile/ Stadium Guide Article] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[Copa América|South American Championship]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Orphan|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox venue | name = Stade Hector-Rolland | address = Allée des soupirs
03000 [[Moulins (Allier)|Moulins]] | coordinates = {{coord|46.57|3.320|type:landmark|display=inline}} | built = 2001 | owners = Ville de [[Moulins (Allier)|Moulins]] | surface = Natural grass | tenants = [[AS Moulins]] | capacity = 2000 places | seating_type = Stands [[:fr:Dragan Miletic|Dragan Miletic]]
(stand of honor)
(1000) | pushpin_map = France }} The '''Hector-Rolland stadium''' is a Stadium located in [[Moulins, Allier|Moulins]], in France, inaugurated in 2001. It is also the stadium for the football club of [[AS Moulins]]CFA (D4) The stadium is named for [[:fr:Hector Rolland|Hector Rolland]], mayor of [[Moulins, Allier|Moulins]] from 1971 to 1989 and [[Member of Parliament|deputy]] of the [[Allier]] from 1968 to 1981 then 1986 to 1988. == External links == * [http://www.asmoulinoise.com/index.php?section=stade Official website of AS Moulins] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2001]] [[Category:Football venues in France]]

{{infobox country at games | NOC = INA | NOCname = [[Indonesian Olympic Committee]] | games = Summer Olympics | year = 1976 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = {{url|www.nocindonesia.or.id }} {{id icon}} | location = [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada | competitors = 7 | sports = 5 | flagbearer = [[Donald Pandiangan]] | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }}
'''[[Indonesia]]''' competed at the '''[[1976 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada.
==Results by event==
===[[Archery at the 1976 Summer Olympics|Archery]]=== In Indonesia's second Olympic archery competition, one man and one woman competed. Only one point separated the scores of the two athletes, though the 2352 points that [[Leane Suniar]] received placed her far higher in the women's ranking than the 2353 points that counterpart [[Donald Pandiangan]] received placed him.
'''Women's Individual Competition''': * [[Leane Suniar]] – 2352 points (→ 9th place)
'''Men's Individual Competition''': * [[Donald Pandiangan]] – 2353 points (→ 19th place)
===[[Athletics at the 1976 Summer Olympics|Athletics]]=== '''Women's Individual Competition:''' ;[[Athletics at the 1976 Summer Olympics – Women's 100 metres|Women's 100 metres]] * [[Carolina Rieuwpassa]] - 11.98 second (Heat 4, 7 place = did not advanced)) ;[[Athletics at the 1976 Summer Olympics – Women's 200 metres|Women's 200 metres]] * [[Carolina Rieuwpassa]] - 24.86 second (Heat 3, 7 place = did not advanced))
===[[Boxing at the 1976 Summer Olympics|Boxing]]=== ;Men's Light-Welterweight * [[Syamsul Anwar Harahap]] - (Round 3 Lost to [[Calistrat Cuțov]]) ;Men's middleweight * [[Frans van Bronckhost]] - (Round 2 Lost to [[Robert Dauer]])
===[[Swimming at the 1976 Summer Olympics|Swimming]]=== ;Men's 100m Freestyle * [[Kris Sumono]] - 55.50 (→ did not advance, Heat 2, 7 place) ;Men's 200m Freestyle * Kris Sumono - 02:01.12 (→ did not advance, Heat 1, 7 place) ;Men's 400 Freestyle * Kris Sumono - 04:17.48 (→ did not advance, Heat 2, 7 place) ;Men's 1500 Freestyle * Kris Sumono - 17:09.17 (→ did not advance, Heat 2, 6 place)
===[[Weightlifting at the 1976 Summer Olympics|Weightlifting]]=== ;Men's 67.5 kg (Lightweight) * Warino Lestanto (17 place) totally 255 kilogrammers
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060622162855/http://www.la84foundation.org/5va/reports_frmst.htm Official Olympic Reports] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131220172441/http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/countries/INA/summer/1976/ Indonesia at the 1976 Montréal Summer Games]
