{{Refimprove|date=November 2018}}
{{Infobox company |name = Kickers |logo = [[Image:KicKers logo.png|150px|Kickers]] |type = [[Privately held company|Private]] |foundation = [[France]] (1970) |location = [[Cholet]], [[France]] |key_people = Daniel Raufast, Founder; Jacques Chevallereau, Designer. |industry = [[Footwear]] |products = Shoes, Apparel |homepage = [http://www.kickers.co.uk/ www.Kickers.co.uk] }}
'''Kickers''' is a youth brand created in 1970 in [[France]] that produces a wide range of [[footwear]] and clothing. Kickers was bought in 2007 by the Royer group.
== History == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Kickersshoes2.JPG|200px|thumb|Kickers shoes 1980]] -->
On the French scene in 1970, Daniel Raufast came across a poster advertising the musical ''[[Hair (musical)|Hair]]''. Interested by all the barefooted youngsters wearing jeans, he developed a new shoe concept which he believed to be more compatible with the blue-jean generation. The designer Jacques Chevallereau then created the first 'jean boot'. This new shoe was very different: the use of [[nubuck]]; shapes that looked more like short boots than regular shoes; tough crepe soles made with [[natural rubber]], [[grommet|eyelets]], contrast stitching, panels and appliqués all obviously referencing [[denim]]. The success was such that, within one season, Kickers production capacity grew from 300 to 12,000 pairs per month. Immediately successful in France, then Germany, by 1974, Kickers were selling in over 70 countries.
=== United Kingdom === <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Kickersshowtags.JPG|200px|thumb|Kickers shoes tags]] -->
During the 1980s Kickers shoes become very successful in Britain. So much so in some case, children were queuing up until 10 o'clock at night waiting upon deliveries, and when the delivery did arrive the stock would be gone in a flash. Many children also collected the ''flower shape'' tag and did not believe the shoes were real Kickers unless this tag was included.<ref>BBC: ''I love 1980'' TV programmes</ref>
== Kick Hi == The Kick Hi boot was released in 1975.
== Music industry popularity == It was in the late 1980s and early 1990s that Kickers really gained popularity when Kick His were heralded by icons on the [[Manchester]] music scene. The Kick Hi then became popular in the [[rave]] scene, first with [[acid house]] and then later with [[trance music]]. Many fans of the shoe came from diverse and contemporary musical backgrounds including [[UK garage]], [[Rhythm and blues|RnB]], [[Pop music|pop]] and [[Hip hop music|hip hop]].
== Popular culture == Over the years, Kickers has been associated with the music industry, including [[Ms Dynamite]], [[So Solid Crew]], [[Jarvis Cocker]], [[Noel Gallagher]], [[The Streets|Mike Skinner]], [[Arctic Monkeys]], [[Craig David]] and [[Rodney P]].
[[Ian Brown]] famously kicked off the trend by wearing a pair of Kick His to [[The Haçienda]] as a cheeky retort to the strict 'no trainer policy'. [[The Stone Roses]] wore them in their video for '[[Fools Gold/What The World Is Waiting For|Fools Gold]]'. A sheep sported a pair of Kick His on the cover of the '[[Stepping Stone (The Farm song)|Stepping Stone]]' 12-inch single by ''[[The Farm (British band)|The Farm]]''.
Kickers sponsored the [[Urban Music Awards]] (UMA) 2007 and had an advertorial with [[NME]] which ended in September 2007.

{{Infobox football biography | name = Miroslav Rede | image = | fullname = Miroslav Rede | birth_date = 1938 | birth_place = [[Kikinda]], [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]] | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | youthyears1 = 1952–1956 | youthclubs1 = [[FK Partizan|Partizan Belgrade]] | years1 = 1956–1959 | years2 = 1959–1961 | years3 = 1961–1962 | years4 = 1962–1967 | clubs1 = [[FK Partizan|Partizan Belgrade]] | clubs2 = [[NK Dinamo Zagreb|Dinamo Zagreb]] | clubs3 = [[FK Rad|Rad Belgrade]] | clubs4 = [[NK Lokomotiva Zagreb|Lokomotiva Zagreb]] | caps1 = 34 | goals1 = 19 }} '''Miroslav Rede''' (born 1938 in [[Kikinda]]) is a [[Croats|Croatian]] sports [[journalist]] and former [[Association football|football]] player.
==Playing career== He started playing in one of the biggest Yugoslav clubs, Belgrade's [[FK Partizan]]. In 1959 he moved, together with his family, to [[Zagreb]], and he started playing for another Yugoslav giants, this time [[NK Dinamo Zagreb]]. After two seasons there, he returned to [[Belgrade]] and played one year with [[FK Rad]] before signing, in 1962, with [[NK Lokomotiva Zagreb]] where he will play the rest of his career, until 1967.
==Sports journalism== After retiring, in 1967, he started working as [[sports journalist]] in Zagreb's [[Sportske novosti]] as a football section editor. At same time, he becomes also the main football editor at the weekly SN Revija magazine. For one year he was the Sports Director of the [[Prva HNL|Croatian First League]] club [[NK Inter Zaprešić|NK Inker Zaprešić]], but in 1993 he returns to journalism, this time to work in the Croatian daily newspaper [[Večernji list]] where he stayed until 2002.
For his work in journalism, he received an award for his life-time work from the Croatian Association of Sports Journalists, and the special journalist award for his coverage of the 1978 FIFA World Cup.
==External sources== * [http://nogomet.lzmk.hr/clanak.aspx?id=2196 Life story] at Nogometni leksikon. {{hr icon}}

Power Alleys: 375 feet
Center Field: 400 feet }} '''Monongalia County Ballpark''' is a baseball stadium in [[Granville, West Virginia]]. The stadium, opened April 10, 2015, is the home of the [[West Virginia Mountaineers baseball|baseball]] team of [[West Virginia University]] (WVU), a member of the [[Big 12 Conference]], and the [[West Virginia Black Bears]] of the [[Class A-Short Season]] [[New York–Penn League]]. ==Construction== Plans were announced to build a new stadium for the [[West Virginia Mountaineers baseball]] team in 2013.{{cite news |title=WVU Board Approves Land Buy for Baseball Stadium|url=http://www.wboy.com/story/22521509/wvu-board-approves-land-buy-for-baseball-stadium|work=[[WBOY-TV|WBOY]]|location=Morgantown|agency=Associated Press|date=June 6, 2013|accessdate=June 7, 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HCcHOMlp|archivedate=June 7, 2013}} Ground was broken for the new ballpark at University Town Centre, an off-campus shopping and entertainment complex in Granville, adjacent to WVU's home city of [[Morgantown, West Virginia|Morgantown]], on October 17, 2013. The ballpark will be a fan friendly design with 2,500 fixed seats with additional hillside and club seating, a fan amenity deck, and a park that will be open year-round.{{cite web |title=New Ballpark|url=http://www.wvusports.com/page.cfm?section=23877|publisher=West Virginia University Department of Intercollegiate Athletics|accessdate=August 21, 2014}} The field will be a synthetic surface, other than the clay pitcher's mound.{{cite web |title=New Ballpark Construction Update|first=Grant|last=Dovey|url=http://www.wvusports.com/page.cfm?story=26127&cat=exclusives|publisher=West Virginia University Department of Intercollegiate Athletics|date=August 21, 2014|accessdate=August 21, 2014}} In August 2014, the [[Jamestown Jammers]] of the [[Class A-Short Season]] [[New York–Penn League]], a [[Minor League Baseball]] affiliate of the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] of [[Major League Baseball]], announced that they would move to West Virginia, taking the name "[[West Virginia Black Bears]]", and use Monongalia County Ballpark as their home stadium.{{cite news |title=Morgantown Lands NY-Penn League Baseball Team|first=Mitch|last=Vingle|url=http://www.wvgazette.com/article/20140823/GZ02/140829703/1115|newspaper=[[The Charleston Gazette]]|date=August 23, 2014|accessdate=August 25, 2014}}{{cite web |title=New NYPL club to be called the Black Bears|url=http://www.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20141022&content_id=99261150&fext=.jsp&vkey=pr_milb&sid=milb|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=October 22, 2014|accessdate=April 15, 2015}} [[File:Mon County Ballpark Pano.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|A panoramic view of the stadium as seen from the third base line.]] As a result of inclement weather in February 2015, the scheduled opening of the stadium was pushed back to April 10, 2015.{{cite web |title=Inclement Weather Delays Scheduled WVU Ballpark Opening|first=Michael|last=Fragale|url=http://www.wvusports.com/blogs.cfm?blog=baseballBlog&story=27589|publisher=West Virginia University Department of Intercollegiate Athletics|date=March 5, 2015|accessdate=May 28, 2015}}{{cite news |title=Wind, Outfield Walls Among Quirks of Monongalia County Ballpark|first=Mike|last=Cassazza|url=http://www.charlestondailymail.com/article/20150409/DM03/150409200|newspaper=[[Charleston Daily Mail]]|date=April 9, 2015|accessdate=April 15, 2015}} [[File:Sandro Calvesi, Guy Drut ed Eddy Ottoz.jpg|thumb|260px|[[Sandro Calvesi]] (left) coach of [[Guy Drut]] (center) and son-in-law, [[Eddy Ottoz]] ([[Brescia]], [[Italy]] 1969)]]
The '''Ottoz family''' is a sporting family consisting of many athletes, one of whom became a manager in the world of [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/1991/06/14/il-vero-maestro-della-famiglia-ottoz.html|title=IL VERO MAESTRO DELLA FAMIGLIA OTTOZ|publisher=repubblica.it|language=Italian|accessdate=25 July 2012|date=14 June 1991|author1=[[Gianni Brera]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ot/eddy-ottoz-1.html|title=Eddy Ottoz - Biography|publisher=sports-reference.com|accessdate=25 July 2012|quote=Father of Laurent Ottoz; Son-in-law of Gabre Gabric-Calvesi.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ga/gabre-gabric-calvesi-1.html|title=Gabre Gabric-Calvesi - Biography|publisher=sports-reference.com|accessdate=25 July 2012|quote=Mother-in-law of Eddy Ottoz; Grandmother of Laurent Ottoz.}}</ref>
[[Sandro Calvesi]] (1913–1980), the ''[[wikt:capostipite|capostipite]]'' of the Calvesi family, coached the [[Italia]]n hurdler [[Eddy Ottoz]], who afterwards became his son-in-law through his marriage with Lyana Calvesi. Calvesi was also the first coach of French Olympic champion [[Guy Drut]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dicorsa.corriere.it/2012/01/22/sandro-calvesi-il-mago-degli-ostacoli/|title=Sandro Calvesi il mago degli ostacoli|publisher=corriere.it|language=Italian|accessdate=25 July 2012|quote=La fama di Sandro Calvesi come mago degli ostacoli era così diffusa anche all’estero che molti campioni stranieri gli chiesero consigli e piani di allenamento, vedi il francese [[Guy Drut]]}}</ref> He was also the promoter of the athletic club, ''Atletica Brescia''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atleticabrescia1950.it/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=58&Itemid=79|title=Atletic Brescia 1950 - Storia|publisher=atleticabrescia1950.it|language=Italian|accessdate=25 July 2012|quote=Il prof. Alessandro Calvesi, classe 1913, campione italiano di 1^ cat. nei 400 hs in gioventù e appassionato allenatore , più tardi tecnico di fama internazionale. Riesce a convincere a venire in aiuto dell’atletica i dirigenti del Brescia calcio e quelli dell’Automobil Club d’Italia.}}</ref>
==History== Calvesi's wife was [[Gabre Gabric-Calvesi|Gabre Gabric]], a former athlete who participated at [[1936 Summer Olympics]] and [[1948 Summer Olympics]]. In 1936 she finished tenth in the [[Athletics at the 1936 Summer Olympics - Women's discus throw|Olympic discus throw event]]. Twelve years later she finished 17th in the [[Athletics at the 1948 Summer Olympics - Women's discus throw|discus throw competition]] at the 1948 Olympics. At the [[1938 European Athletics Championships]] she finished sixth in the discus throw contest and at the [[1946 European Athletics Championships]] she finished seventh in the discus throw event. In 2008 she competed at the Veterans Athletic Championships and,<ref>[http://www.evacs2008.si/lists/Participantlist.htm#Veterans%20W90 16th European Veterans Athletic Championships Ljubljana 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821012711/http://www.evacs2008.si/lists/Participantlist.htm |date=2008-08-21 }}</ref> following the 2011 death of [[Alfred Proksch]], was the last known track and field competitor from the 1936 Olympic Games to still be competing.<ref name="Active">{{cite web|last = Gjerde|first = Arild|author2=Jeroen Heijmans |author3=Bill Mallon |author4=Hilary Evans |title = Revenge of the Last of the Class of ‘36|work = Olympics|publisher = Sports Reference.com|date = 2009-08-04|url = https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/blog/?m=200908|accessdate = 2009-11-15}}</ref>
Gabre Gabric's daughter, Lyana Calvesi (born 1944), is a former athlete who afterward assumed the role of manager of several [[Masters athletics]] teams and before founding the athletic master club, ''Atletica Calvesi''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fidal.it/calendario/IX-MEETING-SANDRO-CALVESI-/COD3348|title=IX MEETING "SANDRO CALVESI"|publisher=fidal.it|language=Italian|date=1 July 2012|accessdate=25 July 2012}}</ref> She married [[Eddy Ottoz]] (born 1944), a former Italian [[hurdling|hurdler]] (bronze medal in [[1968 Summer Olympics]] and 5 times [[European Athletics Championships|European champion]]) before becoming the manager of the [[Italian National Olympic Committee]] from 2001.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportvda.it/politica-premi-e-corsi/386-eddy-ottoz-confermato-nella-giunta-del-qconiq-per-la-terza-volta-insieme-a-gianni-petrucci-ancora-presidente|title=Eddy Ottoz confermato nella Giunta del "Coni" per la terza volta insieme a Gianni Petrucci, ancora presidente|publisher=sportvda.it|language=italian|accessdate=22 October 2012}}</ref> He represented Italy at the [[Athletics at the 1964 Summer Olympics|1964 Summer Olympics]] held in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]], and the [[Athletics at the 1968 Summer Olympics|1968 Summer Olympics]] held in [[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]], where he won the bronze medal in the 110-metre hurdles event.
The couple had three children. [[Laurent Ottoz]] (born 1970) is a former Italian hurdler and member of [[Federazione Italiana di Atletica Leggera|FIDAL]] committee. In 1994 26 years after his father, Laurent Ottoz, broke the national record by completing the [[110 metres hurdles]] in 13:42 seconds in [[Berlin]]. After this he changed event to the [[400 metres hurdles]]. His personal best time is 48:52 seconds, and in Italy only [[Fabrizio Mori]] has a better record.<ref>[http://digilander.libero.it/atleticaleggera/ALL-TIME/15.htm Italian all-time list, men's 400 metres hurdles]</ref> In 1995, Laurent set the fastest automatically recorded time for the rarely run 200 metres low hurdles at 22.55, surpassing the best previously set by [[Colin Jackson]], arguable the best hurdler of that time. His mark is current world best performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dt9guucc6nuua.cloudfront.net/competitioninfo/56eefc4f-3e70-4db7-8eae-fc9c3fcf57ad.pdf|title=Daegu 2011 Statistics Book - Part 1 (of 5)|publisher=iaaf.org|accessdate=11 November 2013}}</ref> [[Patrick Ottoz]] (born 1971) is a former Italian hurdler, while Pilar Ottoz (born 1972), is a former Italian athlete who became a journalist with the Italian public broadcaster, [[RAI]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=54cUqvF50VA|title=Il Sorriso Graffiato|publisher=youtube.com|language=Italian|quote=Il filmato è stato realizzato dalla giornalista RAI, Pilar Ottoz, per il Settimanale della TGR della Valle d'Aosta.|date=7 June 2012|accessdate=25 July 2012}}</ref>

==Records== Members of the Ottoz family set three records at the [[Olympic Stadium (Berlin)|Olympiastadion]] in Berlin. At the [[1936 Summer Olympic Games]], Gabre Gabric, with her 10th place established the [[Italian records in athletics|Italian record]] in [[discus throw]]. Twenty-eight years later in 1964, her son, Eddy Ottoz established the first Italian record of his career in the [[110 meter hurdles]] with a time of 13:9 seconds and, 30 years later in 1994, Gabric's grandson Laurent Ottoz, broke the national record of his own father Eddy, running the 110-metre hurdles in 13:42 seconds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://it.sport.atletica.narkive.com/wwuqTTAS/grande-esempio|title=Grande esempio|publisher=it.sport.atletica.narkive.com|language=Italian|accessdate=25 July 2012|quote=Una curiosità: nello stesso stadio, l'Olympiastadion di Berlino, nel 1936 la nonna si classificò decima ai Giochi, il padre fece il suo primo record italiano il 30 luglio 1964, e il nipote, a trent'anni esatti, il 30 luglio 1994, stabilì il suo primo record nazionale (13"42 nei 100 hs) strappandolo al papà, che ancora lo deteneva...Coincidenza o destino?}}</ref>

caption2 = Satin Wood | image3 = File:Owner John T L Jones Jr.svg | alt3 = Blue, red triple diamond, sleeves and cap | caption3 = Septieme Ciel }} {{Jockey colours footer}} The '''Prix Jean Prat''' is a [[Conditions races|Group 1]] [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in [[France]] open to three-year-old [[thoroughbred]] [[Colt (horse)|colts]] and [[Filly|fillies]]. It is run at [[Chantilly Racecourse|Chantilly]] over a distance of 1,600 metres (about 1 mile), and it is scheduled to take place each year in early July. ==History== The event was established in 1858. It was originally the opening leg of a two-part series called the Prix Biennal. The second leg, for horses aged four or older, was first run in 1859. Both races were staged at [[Longchamp Racecourse|Longchamp]]. The three-year-olds' division of the Prix Biennal was run over 2,000 metres. For a period it was held in April, and it served as a trial for the [[Prix du Jockey Club]]. Both Prix Biennal races were renamed the Prix Jean Prat in 1940. This was in memory of Jean Prat (1847–1940), a successful racehorse owner and breeder. The version for three-year-olds was switched to late May or early June in 1961. It was shortened to 1,850 metres in 1962. It was transferred to Chantilly and cut to 1,800 metres in 1967. The present system of race grading was introduced in 1971, and for several years the event held Group 2 status. The race was promoted to Group 1 level in 1985. From this point the version for older horses was known as the [[Prix Vicomtesse Vigier]]. The Prix Jean Prat returned to Longchamp in 1986. The event started its current period at Chantilly in 1995. It was cut to 1,600 metres and moved to early July in 2005. ==Records== '''Leading [[jockey]] since 1940 (6 wins):''' * [[Yves Saint-Martin]] – ''Jour et Nuit (1964), Silver Shark (1966), Antipode (1974), Earth Spirit (1976), Melyno (1982), Ginger Brink (1983)'' ---- '''Leading [[Horse trainer|trainer]] since 1940 (5 wins):''' * François Mathet – ''Jour et Nuit (1964), Silver Shark (1966), Maroun (1971), Lightning (1977), Melyno (1982)'' * [[François Boutin]] – ''Speedy Dakota (1975), Cresta Rider (1981), Mendez (1984), Baillamont (1985), Priolo (1990)'' * [[André Fabre]] - ''Local Talent (1989), Kitwood (1992), Mutual Trust (2011), Aesop's Fables (2012), Territories (2015)'' ---- '''Leading owner since 1940 (4 wins):''' * [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum|Sheikh Mohammed]] – ''Local Talent (1987), Kitwood (1992), Torrential (1995), Starborough (1997)'' ==Winners since 1977== {| class = "sortable" | border="1" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; font-size:90%" |- bgcolor="#77dd77" align="center" ! {{redirects|Take a knee|the protest initiated by NFL quarterback [[Colin Kaepernick]]| U.S. national anthem protests (2016–present)}}[[Image:DetroitLionsvsGreenBayPackers-2007-FavreKneel.jpg|thumb|right|The Green Bay Packers (right) in the [[kneel]] formation in a game against the Detroit Lions in 2007|330px]] In [[American football]], a '''quarterback kneel''', also called '''taking a knee''', '''genuflect offense''',{{Cn|date=August 2018}} or '''victory formation''' occurs when the [[quarterback]] immediately [[kneels]] to the ground, [[American football rules#Downed player|ending the play on contact]], after receiving the [[snap (football)|snap]]. It is primarily used to [[running out the clock|run the clock down]], either at the end of the first half or the game itself, in order to preserve a lead or a win. Although it generally results in a loss of a yard and uses up a [[Down (gridiron football)|down]], it minimizes the risk of a [[fumble]], which would give the other team a chance at recovering the ball.
Especially when the outcome of the game has been well decided, defenses will often give little resistance to the play as a matter of sportsmanship as well as to reduce the risk of injuries, penalties and possible supplemental discipline (the latter considerations being increasingly important as referees and leagues more strictly enforce penalties against perceived unnecessary roughness on quarterbacks and against headshots in general) on what is a relatively simple play. The quarterback is generally not touched and the act of intentionally taking the knee results in the play being over in all variations of the sport.
The formation offers maximum protection against a fumble; should the center-quarterback exchange result in a fumble, a running back is lined up on either side of the quarterback, both to recover any fumble and protect the vulnerable kneeling player from being injured by defensive players who get through the line. Also, a player is lined up directly behind the quarterback, often much farther than a typical tailback would line up. This player's responsibility is to tackle any defensive player who may recover a fumble and attempt to advance it. Because of this essentially "defensive" responsibility, the tailback in this formation may actually be a free safety or other defensive player who is adept at making tackles in the open field.
Even though the play itself takes very little time, the rules of [[American football]] dictate that it does not stop the game clock (as with any play where the ball carrier is tackled in bounds). With the 40-second play clock in the NFL and NCAA, along with the [[two-minute warning]] in the NFL, a team can run off over two minutes with three straight kneel-downs if the defensive team has no more timeouts. The winning team can storm the field if up to 40 seconds remains in the game (30 in [[Alliance of American Football]]), to let coaches shake hands with each other. (In the AAF, as many as three straight "victory formations" from 90 seconds left in regulation can be done.)
The play is often known as a "victory formation", as it is most often run by a winning team late in the game in order to preserve a victory. In the case of a close game, the winning team would be trying to avoid a turnover which might be the result of a more complex play. In the case of a more lopsided contest where the winning team's overall [[point differential]] has no prospect of affecting their playoff qualification prospects, the play can be run as a matter of sportsmanship (since the winning team foregoes the opportunity to [[running up the score|run up the score]]) and to avoid further injuries and/or penalties. In terms of statistics, a kneel by the quarterback is typically recorded as a rushing attempt for −1 or −2 yards.
Other sports also use the term "victory formation" for a play designed only to run down the clock with little chance of injury, such as a Jammer in [[roller derby]] skating behind or only lightly challenging the pack while the final seconds of the bout tick down.
==Strategy== The quarterback kneel is mainly used when the team in the lead has possession of the ball with less than two minutes on the game clock. With the 40-second play clock in the NFL and NCAA, two minutes (120 seconds) is in theory the maximum amount of time that can be run off on three consecutive quarterback kneels; this assumes it is first down and the defense has no timeouts remaining. A team cannot run more than three consecutive quarterback kneels as doing so on fourth down turns the ball over to the opponent and guarantees them at least one opportunity to score. The decision to run the quarterback kneel depends on the amount of time remaining in the game, the down, and the number of timeouts the defense has remaining. For example, if there is one minute remaining on the game clock on first down, and the defense has one timeout left, the offense may use two successive quarterback kneels to completely run out the clock, and if the defense uses its timeout the offense can simply run a third kneel to run out the clock. However, if there is one minute remaining on the game clock on ''third'' down, then regardless of how many timeouts the defense has, quarterback kneels will not completely run out the clock and the offense must try to make a first down. AAF allows this to happen if up to 90 seconds remain; there's a 30-second play clock.
The quarterback kneel is also often used at the end of the first half by a team which feels they have little chance of scoring before halftime due to poor field position. It is also sometimes run at the end of the second half of a tie game by a team content with sending the game into overtime. Less commonly, the play is sometimes run at the end of the game by a losing team which is hopelessly behind and wishes to avoid injury, but is unwilling to cut the game short by [[forfeit (sport)|forfeiting]].
A team that is in field-goal range and either tied on the score or trailing by 1 or 2 points can also use one or more kneeldowns in order to run time off the clock before attempting a field goal. A quarterback in this situation may also run several yards to his left or right before kneeling down in order to get a more favorable spot for the field goal attempt, in order to try and get the ball closer to the goal line and/or to get the ball to a particular set of hash marks if the team's kicker prefers to kick from a specific side of the field. Ideally, the clock would run out during the field goal attempt, thereby preventing the opposing team from getting an opportunity to score again.
In several instances (including twice by the [[2017 Philadelphia Eagles season|Philadelphia Eagles]] in the [[2017 NFL season]]), a quarterback kneel has been purposefully initiated on a [[Conversion (gridiron football)|point after touchdown]] try at the end of the game after a game-winning or defensive touchdown was scored at the end of regulation; NFL rules used to require the try to be executed between the offense and defense, even if the offense intends to decline the unnecessary points to avoid further insulting or annoying their opponent. This occurred prominently in the 2018 "[[Minneapolis Miracle]]", where eight [[2017 New Orleans Saints season|New Orleans Saints]] players on offense and defense had to return to the field from the locker room to 'oppose' the try against the victorious [[2017 Minnesota Vikings season|Minnesota Vikings]] after referee imploration to complete the try. Quarterback [[Case Keenum]] merely knelt the ball down before tossing it in the air and celebrating the Viking victory, with the Saints giving no effort to strip the ball (as a defensive runback for a two-point conversion would not have assured a tie or victory).<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/watch-case-keenum-leads-skol-chant-after-throwing-game-winning-td-in-playoffs/|title=Case Keenum leads Skol chant after throwing game-winning TD in playoffs|last=Blackburn|first=Pete|date=14 January 2018|publisher=[[CBS Sports]]|accessdate=15 January 2018}}</ref> The rule was changed for 2018 onward, to omit the try if it would have no impact on the outcome of the game.
In rare instances, a team will use the quarterback kneel to avoid [[running up the score]] in a lopsided contest, even though there may be significant time remaining on the clock. This occurred in the 2011 edition of the [[Magnolia Bowl]] between the [[2011 LSU Tigers football team|LSU Tigers]] and [[2011 Ole Miss Rebels football team|Ole Miss Rebels]]. With five minutes remaining and LSU leading 52–3, Tigers' head coach [[Les Miles]] ordered third-string quarterback [[Zach Mettenberger]] to kneel on first and goal from the Ole Miss one-yard line, and to kneel on the next three plays. Miles felt another touchdown would further embarrass Ole Miss coach [[Houston Nutt]], who announced his resignation, effective at the end of the season, 12 days before the Rebels hosted first-ranked LSU. The Tigers had already secured the largest margin of victory in series history.
In [[Canadian football]], which use slightly different rules, kneeling with time left is not necessarily a viable strategy. Unlike in American football, in Canadian football every quarter must end with a play even in situations where the game clock expires after the end of the previous play. However, a quarterback kneel is by far the most common play for winning teams to run with ''"zeros on the clock"'' at the end of a game, barring exceptional (but not unheard-of) situations where the head-to-head point differential in the opposing teams' season series (a key factor in tiebreakers) remains in doubt.
==History== Prior to the mid-1970s, teams leading in the final moments of games generally ran quarterback sneaks (which brought the risk of injuries on low-yardage plays) or dive plays to the fullbacks or other running backs to run time off the clock, as some coaches considered kneeling cowardly or even unsportsmanlike. However, the [[Miracle at the Meadowlands]], on November 19, {{nfly|1978}}, in which defensive back [[Herman Edwards]] of the visiting [[1978 Philadelphia Eagles season|Philadelphia Eagles]] recovered a botched handoff between quarterback [[Joe Pisarcik]] and running back [[Larry Csonka]] of the [[1978 New York Giants season|New York Giants]], provided a nationally-televised spur for change.
With 31 seconds remaining, the Giants led 17–12 and the Eagles were out of timeouts.<ref name=sivrup>{{cite news |url=https://www.si.com/vault/1978/11/27/106773446/a-roundup-of-the-week-nov-1319 |magazine=Sports Illustrated |last=Chen |first=Albert |title=A roundup of the week Nov 13-19: pro football |date=November 27, 1978 |page=116}}</ref><ref name=sivfum>{{cite news |url=https://www.si.com/vault/2001/07/02/306829/the-fumble-it-was-one-of-the-great-blunders-in-nfl-history-all-the-giants-had-to-do-was-run-out-the-clock-instead-they-unleashed-a-disaster-that-altered-the-course-of-several-careers |magazine=Sports Illustrated |last=Chen |first=Albert |title=The fumble |date=July 2, 2001 |page=116}}</ref> As Pisarcik attempted to hand it to [[Larry Csonka]], it was awkwardly fumbled; Edwards scooped it up and ran it 26 yards for the Eagles' improbable {{nowrap|19–17 victory.<ref name=fplnmr>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fvQhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=naAFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6100%2C8133172 |work=Reading Eagle |location=(Pennsylvania) |agency=Associated Press |title=Final play nightmare |date=November 20, 1978 |page=29}}</ref><ref name=alnyny>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=m0UuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MlkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4969%2C2761929 |work=Pittsburgh Press |agency=UPI |title=Alas, New York, New York |date=November 20, 1978 |page=B=6 }}</ref>}} The play generated tremendous controversy, ridicule, and criticism toward the Giants nationwide and specifically offensive coordinator [[Bob Gibson (American football)|Bob Gibson]] for failing to use the supposedly foolproof quarterback-kneeldown play.
In the week following the game, both the Eagles and Giants developed specific formations designed to protect the quarterback behind three players as he fell on the ball. Previously, quarterbacks executing a similar "kill the clock" play simply ran a quarterback sneak from a tightly packed conventional offensive formation. The Eagles made the [[1978–79 NFL playoffs|playoffs]] and the Giants finished at {{nowrap|6–10.}}
The "victory formation" spread rapidly throughout football at nearly all levels, as coaches sought to adopt a procedure for downing the ball in the final seconds which would reduce the risk of turnovers to the absolute minimum possible. Within a season or so, it had become nearly universal. In 1987 the NFL rule allowing quarterbacks to simply kneel and not have to fall down and risk a hit from the defense took effect.
==Defense==
Although in most instances a losing team will concede defeat when the other team is in the victory formation and taking the quarterback kneel, there are instances where the trailing team will try to make a defensive play in an attempt to regain possession of the ball, particularly when the losing team is behind by a touchdown or less and there is enough time to make more than one play.
[[Image:Post-Pisarcik QB kneel formation.svg|thumb|200px|right|Formation adopted for the quarterback kneel play after the Miracle at the Meadowlands]] This had happened on the play preceding [[The Miracle at the Meadowlands]]. Due to the low percentage of turnovers caused, defenses generally do not attempt to disrupt the kneeldown as the Eagles did in 1978; a "gentlemen's agreement" emerged in which defenders did not rush the offensive team with high intensity, as long as the offense made no attempt to advance the ball.
One prominent exception occurred to another Giants quarterback in 2012. In Week 2, an interception of a [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] pass with six seconds left had apparently secured a 25-point fourth-quarter comeback and 41–34 Giant victory. However, in the ensuing "victory formation" play, instead of the usual nominal contact between the lineman, the Buccaneers stacked the line of scrimmage and forcefully pushed the Giants' line back in an attempt to cause Giants' QB [[Eli Manning]] to fumble. Manning was knocked back by his own center as he took the snap and fell down. Giants coach [[Tom Coughlin]] angrily confronted his Tampa Bay counterpart, [[Greg Schiano]], at midfield once the game was over.<ref>Garafalo, Mike, "Coughlin to Schiano: 'You don't do that in this league'", ''[[USA Today]]'', September 17, 2012. Accessed September 17, 2012. [http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gameon/post/2012/09/16/coughlin-schiano-yelling/70000471/1#.UFdGmq5li6U]</ref> Undaunted, Schiano employed a similar strategy the next week at the end of the Buccaneers' game against the [[Dallas Cowboys]]. In the [[2013 NFL season|next season]], with the Philadelphia Eagles leading the Buccaneers, [[Chip Kelly]] had [[quarterback]] [[Nick Foles]] attempt a [[shotgun formation]] kneeldown to avert Schiano's aggressive technique, which succeeded.
Aside from trying to attempt a defensive play, teams that are losing but behind by a touchdown or less in the final two minutes will sometimes use their time-outs if the team does a quarterback kneel. As teams are allowed three time-outs per half—the clock stops on a time out and restarts on the snap—they will try to preserve them for situations such as this, thereby forcing the winning team to run a play and gain a first down or, in the very least, take time off the clock.
If there is still enough time left on the clock and the winning team attempts another quarterback kneel, the defensive team's strategy may repeat itself until it either runs out of time-outs, time runs out, or (most desirably) the team forces a punt or turnover, though in 2016, the [[Baltimore Ravens]], leading in a game against the [[Cincinnati Bengals]] after three plays, ran off the remaining twelve seconds of clock off in a punt formation with [[Sam Koch]] purposefully holding the ball in the end zone while multiple [[Holding (American football)|holding]] calls were made against the Ravens offense. The play ended with Koch touching his toe to the back end zone line after time expired and taking an intentional [[Safety (gridiron football score)|safety]] (offensive fouls at the end of the game do not result in a replay of a down, unlike their defensive equivalents). The intentional holding aspect of the play was made illegal after the 2016 NFL season.
==Rules== The 2011 NFL Rules state in Rule 7, Section 2, Article 1(c): "An official shall declare the ball dead and the down ended … when a quarterback immediately drops to his knee (or simulates dropping to his knee) behind the line of scrimmage".<ref>{{Citation |author=[[National Football League]] |date=2011 |title=Official Playing Rules and Casebook of the National Football League |page=35 |url=http://static.nfl.com/static/content/public/image/rulebook/pdfs/10_Rule7_BallInPlay_DeadBall_Scrimm.pdf |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref>
The 2011 and 2012 NCAA Rules state in Rule 4, Section 1, Article 3(o): "A live ball becomes dead and an official shall sound his whistle or declare it dead … When a ball carrier simulates placing his knee on the ground."<ref>{{Citation |author=[[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] |date=May 2011 |title=2011 and 2012 NCAA Football Rules and Interpretations |page=FR-56 |url=http://www.ncaapublications.com/productdownloads/FR12.pdf |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref> The same rule is used by the [[British American Football Association]].<ref>{{Citation |author=[[British American Football Association]] |year=2012 |title=Football Rules and Interpretations, 2012-13 edition |url=http://rules.bafra.org/rules/rulebook/2012/4.pdf |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref>
The 2011 CFL Rules state in Rule 1, Section 4: "The ball is dead … When the quarterback, in possession of the ball, intentionally kneels on the ground during the last three minutes of a half".<ref>{{Citation|author=[[Canadian Football League]] |year=2011 |title=The Official Playing Rules for the Canadian Football League |page=14 |url=https://www.cfl.ca/uploads/assets/CFL/PDF_Docs/CFL_Rule_Book_2011.pdf |accessdate=12 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511072051/http://www.cfl.ca/uploads/assets/CFL/PDF_Docs/CFL_Rule_Book_2011.pdf |archivedate=May 11, 2012 }}</ref> The Statistical Scoring Rules, Section 5(e) states: "When a quarterback voluntarily drops to one knee and concedes yards in an effort to run out the clock, the yards lost will be charged under Team Losses. NOTE – No quarterback sack will be given in this situation."<ref>{{Citation|author=[[Canadian Football League]] |year=2011 |title=The Official Playing Rules for the Canadian Football League |pages=82, 88 |url=https://www.cfl.ca/uploads/assets/CFL/PDF_Docs/CFL_Rule_Book_2011.pdf |accessdate=12 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511072051/http://www.cfl.ca/uploads/assets/CFL/PDF_Docs/CFL_Rule_Book_2011.pdf |archivedate=May 11, 2012 }}</ref>

revision.comment: /* Dive roll */Fixing [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links|links to disambiguation pages]], replaced: [[diving]] → [[Diving (sport)|diving]]
revision.text:
{{confusing|date=December 2011}} A '''roll''' is the most basic and fundamental skill in gymnastics. There are many variations in the skill. Rolls are similar to [[Flip (acrobatic)|flips]] in the fact that they are a complete rotation of the body, but the rotation of the roll is usually made on the ground while a flip is made in the air with the hips passing over the head and without any hands touching the ground. Rolls also help recover from a fall safely.<ref>{{cite book|last=Sands, Caine, Borms|first=Bill, Dennis John, Jan|title=Scientific Aspects of Women's Gymnastics:Volume 45 of Medicine and sport science, 0254-5020|year=2003|publisher=Karger Publishers|isbn=3805574762|page=27}}</ref>
==Forward roll== [[File:Gymnastics-training-08038.jpg|thumb|right|A child performing a forward roll]] The forward roll (colloquially called a roly poly) is one of the most basic elements in gymnastics and one of the first learnt.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sportacademy/hi/sa/special_events/gymnastics/newsid_3855000/3855893.stm|title=Take to the floor with Tweddle!|publisher=BBC Sport|date= 2004-07-13|accessdate=2010-11-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Sands, Caine, Borms|first=Bill, Dennis John, Jan|title=Scientific Aspects of Women's Gymnastics:Volume 45 of Medicine and sport science, 0254-5020|year=2003|publisher=Karger Publishers|isbn=3805574762|page=27}}</ref> The forward roll is started from a standing position and then the gymnast crouches down, places their hands shoulder wide apart and hands facing forward. They tuck their chin to their chest and place the back of their head onto the floor.<ref name="Gymnastics - floor exercises">{{cite video| people=BBC Sports Academy| accessdate=2010-11-15| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/learningzone/clips/6272.bb.wmv| title=Gymnastics - floor exercises| medium=Television production| location=UK| publisher=BBC Sports Academy}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> They then push off of the floor with their legs and rotate over their head onto their back. The gymnast then presses their feet onto the floor and whips the arms forward to stand up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/scotland/education/bitesize/standard/other/sos/pe/evaluating/answerevaluating_03.shtml|title=Ask a Teacher - Physical Education - Evaluating|publisher=BBC Bitesize|date=|accessdate=2010-11-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090510024632/http://www.bbc.co.uk/scotland/education/bitesize/standard/other/sos/pe/evaluating/answerevaluating_03.shtml|archivedate=2009-05-10|df=}}</ref> [[File:Jahn-Bergturnfest 2009 gymnastics.jpg|thumb|right|A child performing a forward roll]]
==Backward roll== The backward roll is similar to the forward roll, but in reverse. The gymnast starts in a standing position and bends to a [[Squatting position|squat/sitting position]] with their arms in front. They then lower and lean back slightly until their bottom reaches the floor. They then continue this momentum and roll over their back onto their shoulders. They should then place their hands next to their shoulders and tuck their head into their chin. The hands then push the floor strongly and straighten their arms and continue to rotate their body over their head. The feet are then placed on the floor and the gymnast stands.<ref name="Gymnastics - floor exercises"/>
Variations: *'''Backward roll to [[handstand]]''' - This is essentially the same as a backward roll, however when the hands make contact with the ground, they straighten fully and the body continues to straighten upwards into a handstand position. *'''Backward roll on [[Rings (gymnastics)|rings]]''' - This is the same movement as a backward roll but it is performed on rings. It can also be used in a combination such as backwards roll to Maltese.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.intlgymnast.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2127:mitchell-dominates-dtb-cup-with-three-golds&catid=5:competition-reports&Itemid=164|title=Mitchell Dominates DTB Cup with Three Golds|publisher=International Gymnast Magazine |date= |accessdate=2010-11-15}}</ref> *'''Shoulder roll''' – This is similar to a backward roll but the roll is performed over one shoulder rather than pushing with the arms and rolling over the head. This is more commonly performed in [[Rhythmic Gymnastics]], as it is faster and it also protects the hair.
==Sideways roll== A sideways roll is also known as a log roll, barrel roll, or pencil roll. This can be started by lying down on the back or front with the body outstretched. The gymnast then rolls onto their side and does a complete rotation of the body, remaining parallel to the performing surface.<ref>{{cite book|last=Human Kinetics|title=The Sports Rules Book|year=2009|publisher=Human Kinetics 1|isbn=1450408109|page=64}}</ref> The log roll is a sideways roll with the hands next to the waist and the pencil roll is with the hands stretched above the head. A sideways roll can also be performed when a gymnast over-rotates or loses their balance in a vertical, forward or sideways direction.<ref name=laban1>Debby Mitchell, Barbara Davis, Raim Lopez (2009) "Teaching fundamental gymnastics skills", {{ISBN|0-7360-0124-7}}, Chapter 1: "Gymnastics Basics: Teaching Safely, Teaching Well", section "Side Rolls"</ref>
==Tucked sideways roll== A Tucked Sideways roll begins with the gymnast starting in a kneeling position, with the gymnast sitting back onto their heels with their head and arms in an outstretched position like the [[Balasana|child pose]] in yoga. From here, the gymnast rolls onto their side with their legs maintaining the tucked position and onto their knees again.<ref name=laban2>British Gymnastics (2009) "Gymnastics", {{ISBN|978-0-7136-8952-5}}, Chapter 8: "The Family of Rolls", section "Tucked Sideways Roll"</ref>
==Tin soldier roll/Teddy bear roll== This roll starts by sitting on the floor in a straddle position. The legs are held below the knees and the body leans over towards the shoulder on one side. The gymnast then folds more tightly until they roll over their back and return to a sitting straddle position.<ref name=laban3>British Gymnastics (2009) "Gymnastics", {{ISBN|978-0-7136-8952-5}}, Chapter 8: "The Family of Rolls", section "Tin Soldier Roll"</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://schools.norfolk.gov.uk/myportal/custom/files_uploaded/uploaded_resources/2303/gymaction_card1.doc|title=Gymnastic Resource Card 1S|publisher=|date=|accessdate=2010-11-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20111011103737/http%3A//schools.norfolk.gov.uk/myportal/custom/files_uploaded/uploaded_resources/2303/gymaction_card1.doc|archivedate=2011-10-11|df=}}</ref>
==Dive roll== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-37600-0006, Leipzig, DHfK, Gymnastik.jpg|thumb|left|Dive Roll]] [[File:Dive Roll over Table.gif|thumb|right|Dive Roll Over Table]] A [[dive roll]] is an acrobatic stunt that begins with a horizontal forward [[Diving (sport)|diving]] motion and results in a forward roll. Alternate forms such as a Jigaree are also notable. It is considered an advanced forward roll, demonstrating flight and a smooth landing.<ref>{{cite book|last=LeBoeuf & Butler|first=Maureen & Lawrence|title=Fit and Active: The West Point Physical Development Program|year=2008|publisher=Human Kinetics 1, 2008|isbn=073606074X|page=36}}</ref> It is also used in other sports such as wrestling to reinforce the motion of landing correctly.<ref>{{cite book|last=Cejudo & Roth|first=Henry & Jillian|title=Wrestling For Dummies|year=2012|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=1118117972|pages=384}}</ref>

{{Infobox recurring event | name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | status = defunct | genre = | date = March | begins = | ends = | frequency = Annually | venue = | location = [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] and [[Gateshead]], [[Tyne and Wear]], [[UK]] | coordinates = | country = | years_active = | first = {{Start date|1994|df=y}} | founder_name = | last = {{End date|2018|df=y}} | prev = | next = | participants = [[Newcastle University]]
[[Northumbria University]] | attendance = | area = | budget = | activity = | patron = | organised = | filing = | people = | member = | sponsor = | website = {{URL|stancalvert.co.uk}} | footnotes = Northumbria University {{small|(current holder)}} }} The '''Stan Calvert Cup''', formally known as the '''Stan Calvert Memorial Cup''', was an annual varsity contest that takes place in [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] between the universities of [[Newcastle University|Newcastle]] and [[Northumbria University|Northumbria]] formerly in December and February, before moving to March. The annual cup ran from 1994 to 2018, before being officially cancelled at the start of the 2018 academic year when Newcastle made the decision to withdraw from the competition{{Cite web|url=https://northumbriasport.com/news/an-update-on-the-stan-calvert-memorial-cup|title=Northumbria Sport : News : An update on the Stan Calvert memorial cup|website=northumbriasport.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-10-10}} .{{cite web |last1=Parsons |first1=Harry |title=Breaking news: Stan Calvert cancelled |url=http://thecourieronline.co.uk/stan-calvert-cancelled/ |website=The Courier |publisher=The Courier |accessdate=10 October 2018}} == The competition == It is named for Stan Calvert, a man from nearby [[Alnwick]], who became involved with sport at the University of Newcastle in the early 1960s and was the university's first Director of Sporthttps://www.ncl.ac.uk/nclsport/events/calvert/ from 1981.https://www.ncl.ac.uk/nclsport/events/dates/item/stan-calvert-cup-gets-underway The competition does not take place in a single sporting event but rather over 1200 competitors in more than 70 teams compete against each other in 26 different sports, the winning university is determined by whose team won the most events. The competition has taken place every year since its formation in 1994. The current rules that determine the nature of the competition were signed by both universities in 2009. == Previous winners == Since 1994, Newcastle University has won the cup 13 times and Northumbria has won 10 times. There have also been 2 draws. In 2013 Team Newcastle ensured the Stan Calvert Memorial Trophy was retained for an unprecedented 6th consecutive year. For the first time in seven years, Northumbria University reclaimed the trophy from Newcastle University and are the current holders of the cup after a heroic effort to retain the cup for the first time in their history, winning by their biggest margin ever in the process,{{cite web |url=http://thecourieronline.co.uk/newcastles-stan-calvert-supremacy-smashed/ |title=Newcastle’s Stan Calvert supremacy smashed |publisher=The Courier |date=20 March 2014 |accessdate=4 July 2014}} before winning the competition again in 2016, 2017 and 2018.{{Cite web|url=http://nusportcentral.com/team-northumbria/stan-calvert-memorial-cup-games#so-what-is-stan-calvert|title=Stan Calvert {{!}} Team Northumbria {{!}} NU Sport Central|website=nusportcentral.com|access-date=2016-05-12}}{{Cite web|url=http://nusportcentral.com/news/hat-trick-of-stan-calvert-wins-tastes-sweet|title=Hat-trick Of Stan Calvert Wins Tastes Sweet {{!}} News {{!}} NU Sport Central|website=nusportcentral.com|access-date=2016-05-12}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! revision.text:
[[File:John Sebastian 1979.jpg|thumb|[[John Sebastian]] performed at Parr Meadows in 1979]]
'''Suffolk Meadows''' was a [[American Quarter Horse|quarter horse]] racing facility on [[Long Island]] that operated during 1977 and 1986. The racetrack was situated on a {{convert|65|acres|km2|sing=on}} parcel located in [[Yaphank, New York|Yaphank]] northwest of the [[County Route 46 (Suffolk County, New York)|William Floyd Parkway]] interchange on the [[Interstate 495 (New York)|Long Island Expressway]].
The racetrack first opened in 1977 as '''Parr Meadows''' and closed following a 113-day meet after the bank defaulted on loans. Although the track was not built by developer Ron Parr, the Parr Organization assumed ownership after the original builder ran out of funds.<ref>{{cite news |title=1949: Parr Brothers Join in Building Suburbia |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4189/is_20040109/ai_n16160361/ |newspaper=Long Island Business News |date=January 9, 2004 |accessdate=2010-02-12}}</ref><ref name="libiznews-2009-05-15">{{cite news |title=I Came Upon a Child of God, He Was Walking the LIE |first=John |last=Kominicki |url=http://libn.com/blog/2009/05/15/kominicki-i-came-upon-a-child-of-god-he-was-walking-the-lie/ |newspaper=Long Island Business News |date=May 15, 2009 |accessdate=2010-02-12}}</ref><ref name="newsday-2009-08-06">{{cite news |title=Remembering the 1979 Yaphank concert at Parr Meadows |first=Bill |last=Bleyer |url=http://www.exploreli.com/going-out/music/remembering-the-1979-yaphank-concert-at-parr-meadows-1.1350964 |newspaper=Newsday |date=August 6, 2009 |accessdate=2010-02-12}}</ref> In May 1986, horse racing briefly returned to Suffolk Meadows for an 86-day stint. The racetrack ceased operations on October 18, 1986.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.racing.ny.gov/AnnualReports/annualreport1986.pdf |title=N.Y. State Racing & Wagering Board Annual Report 1986 |work=New York State Racing and Wagering Board |accessdate=2010-02-12 }}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref>
On September 7, 1979, 18,000 attendees gathered at Parr Meadows for a ten-hour concert featuring a number of the original performers from the [[Woodstock Festival]]. Musical artists attending the tenth year reunion concert included [[Blondie Chaplin]], [[Canned Heat]], [[Country Joe McDonald]], [[John Sebastian]], [[Leslie West]], [[Jorma Kaukonen]], [[Johnny Winter]], [[Paul Butterfield]], [[Rick Danko]] and [[Stephen Stills]]. Many of the concertgoers arrived the day before, parking along William Floyd Parkway and camping out in the woods.<ref name="libiznews-2009-05-15"/><ref name="newsday-2009-08-06"/>
Suffolk Meadows has also been the site of competitions for the International Professional Rodeo Association and the Suffolk County Fair.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Guide |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/08/28/nyregion/the-guide-187488.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=August 28, 1988 |accessdate=2010-02-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Long Island Guide |first=Barbara |last=Delatiner |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/10/nyregion/long-island-guide.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=May 10, 1998 |accessdate=2010-02-12}}</ref> The former racetrack site has also been discussed as a potential location of a casino for the [[Shinnecock Indian Nation]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Shinnecock Resurgence |first=Dan |last=Rattiner |authorlink=Dan Rattiner |url=http://www.danshamptons.com/content/danspapers/issue06_2009/05.html |newspaper=Dan's Papers |date=May 1, 2009-05 |accessdate=2010-02-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121010144/http://danshamptons.com/content/danspapers/issue06_2009/05.html |archivedate=November 21, 2010 |df= }}</ref> In 1997, developer [[Wilbur Breslin]] planned to develop the adjacent property into a regional shopping mall called Brookhaven Town Center.<ref>{{cite news |title=Plans for Yaphank Mall Put Builder Under Fire |first=John |last=Rather |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/27/nyregion/plans-for-yaphank-mall-put-builder-under-fire.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=July 27, 1997 |accessdate=2010-02-12}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100210055332/http://www.lioddities.com/Bygone/horsetrack.htm Suffolk Meadows at LI Oddities]

{{Infobox golf facility | name = Tryall Golf Club | image = | imagesize = | caption = | pushpin_map = Jamaica | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption= | coordinates = {{coord|18.4475|-78.0583|type:landmark_region:JM|display=inline,title}} | location = [[Montego Bay]], [[Hanover Parish, Jamaica|Hanover]], [[Jamaica]] | establishment = 1958 | type = Private | owner = | operator = | holes = Eighteen | tournaments = [[The Jamaica Classic]] (1989–1991)
[[Johnnie Walker World Golf Championship]] (1991–1995) | website = {{URL|www.tryallclub.com}} | course1 = | designer1 = [[Ralph Plummer]] | par1 = | length1 = {{convert|6800|yd|m}} | rating1 = | slope1 = | record1 = | image2 = | imagesize2 = | caption2 = }} '''Tryall Golf Club''' is a private [[country club]] in [[Hanover Parish, Jamaica]], just outside [[Montego Bay]]. Founded in 1958 and designed by [[Ralph Plummer]], it features a 6,800 yard 18-hole course. In 1963, it hosted [[Shell's Wonderful World of Golf]] match between [[Dow Finsterwald]] and [[Peter Alliss]]. It also hosted the [[LPGA Tour]]'s [[The Jamaica Classic]] from 1989 to 1991 and the unofficial [[PGA Tour]] event [[Johnnie Walker World Golf Championship]] from 1991 to 1995. In 2005, it was voted the Best Golf course in the Caribbean by [[CaribbeanWorld Magazine]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080719230103/http://www.golfclubatlas.com/tryall1.html Country club history] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061122180941/http://www.tryallclub.com/web.asp?bestgolf Award] [[Category:Golf clubs and courses in Jamaica]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Hanover Parish]] {{Golfcourse-stub}} {{Jamaica-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Use British English|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = Umbro | logo = Logo Umbro.png | logo_size = 200px | image = | image_size = 500 | image_alt = | image_caption = | trading_name = | native_name = | former_name = | type = [[Subsidiary]] | traded_as = | ISIN = | founded = {{Start date and age|df=yes|1924|05|23}} in [[Wilmslow]], England | founder = Harold & Wallace Humphreys | hq_location = | hq_location_city = [[Cheadle, Greater Manchester|Cheadle]],
[[Greater Manchester]] | hq_location_country = [[England]] | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = | brands = | industry = [[Textile industry|Textile]] | products = {{collapsible list| * [[Association football|Football]] [[Kit (association football)|uniforms]], [[Kit (association football)#Other equipment|goalkeeper gloves]], [[Ball (association football)|balls]], [[Football boots|boots]] * [[Sportswear (activewear)|Sportswear]] }} | parent = [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] (2007-2012)
[[Iconix Brand Group]] (2012-present) | homepage = [http://www.umbro.com umbro.com] | caption = ''The heart & soul of football'' | num_employees = 1,678 }} '''Umbro''' is an [[England|English]] [[Sportswear (activewear)|sportswear]] and [[association football|football]] equipment supplier based in [[Cheadle, Greater Manchester|Cheadle]], next to [[Manchester]], [[England]]. Umbro designs, sources, and markets football-related apparel, footwear, and equipment. Its products are sold in over 90 countries worldwide. Since 2012, the company has been a subsidiary of American company [[Iconix Brand Group]].[http://www.iconixbrand.com/umbro_history.html Umbro at Iconix Brand website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130210041507/http://www.iconixbrand.com/umbro_history.html |date=10 February 2013 }}, retrieved 11 February 2013 ==History== ===Beginning and expansion=== The company was founded by Harold Humphreys, along with his brother Wallace in a small workshop in [[Wilmslow]], [[Cheshire]], inspired by the growing interest in [[association football|football]] witnessed nationwide. The name "Umbro" is a quasi-[[portmanteau]] inspired by Humphreys Brothers Clothing. Umbro's kit debut was in the 1934 [[FA Cup]] final, when both teams [[Manchester City]] and [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] wore kits designed and manufactured by the company. Other teams supplied by Umbro during the 1930s and 1940s were [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]], [[Preston North End W.F.C.|Preston North End]], [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]]. Umbro was the official sports manufacturer of the English [[FA Cup]] and official sponsor of [[The Football Association|The FA]], being the exclusive supplier of [[football (ball)|balls]] to the body's leagues. In 1952, the British team at the [[Summer Olympics]] wore Umbro kits, tailored for the needs of their individual sports. Umbro would supply kits for the British Olympics team for the next 20 years. In 1957, Umbro entered the [[tennis]] market, producing sports clothing in collaboration with player [[Ted Tinling]]. This collaboration extended for three decades. Another sportsman who collaborated with Umbro was [[Manchester United]] manager [[Matt Busby]], in 1959. That same year the company started to sell its junior boys' kits, a set of shirt, shorts and socks that would allow young players to wear the same look as their footballing idols. [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] became the first [[FIFA World Cup]] champion to wear kits by Umbro in [[1958 World Cup|1958]]. Two years later, Manchester United [[Scotland|Scottish]] player [[Denis Law]] signed an exclusive agreement with the brand, becoming the first footballer to be sponsored by Umbro. The [[England national football team|England national team]] won its only title in [[1966 World Cup|1966]] wearing kits by Umbro (the deal had been signed in 1954). Of the 16 teams that competed, 15 wore kit manufactured by Umbro,[http://www.umbro.com/en-gb/about-umbro/ Umbro history website], retrieved 27 March 2013 the only exception being the [[Soviet Union national football team|USSR]]. At the same time, 85% of British football teams wore kits by the company, including [[Glasgow Celtic|Celtic]], the first British team to win a [[European Cup]] in 1967. Liverpool FC won the first four of their five European Cups while wearing Umbro kits, in 1977, 1978, 1981 and 1984. In 1974, Umbro's founder, Harold Humphreys, died. His sons John and Stuart took over the running of the company. The [[England national football team|England national team]] wore Umbro shirts by choice until 1974, when [[The Football Association]], encouraged by the England manager [[Don Revie]], sold the jersey manufacturing rights to [[Admiral Sportswear]]. After more than a decade wearing Admiral kits, the England national team signed with Umbro again in 1984. In 1986, Umbro began to manufacture its own [[football boot]]s. The company added footballers [[Alan Shearer]] and [[Michael Owen]] (who was only 14 years old) to its list of sponsored athletes. In 1994, Brazil won its fourth FIFA World Cup title in the [[1994 FIFA World Cup|United States]] and club teams [[AFC Ajax]] (in 1995), and Manchester United (in 1999) obtained the [[UEFA Champions League]] and the [[Intercontinental Cup (football)|Intercontinental Cup]], in [[National Stadium Tokyo|Tokyo]], all of them wearing Umbro kits. In the United States, Umbro was the majority owner (94%) of [[United Soccer Leagues]], the parent organization for North America's lower division men's soccer (tiers two through four in the American Soccer Pyramid), and the second tier women's league (W-League) and youth league (Super Y-League).{{cite news |url=http://www.uslsoccer.com/home/124750.html |title= Umbro increases share of USL ownership |publisher=USL Soccer |date=16 March 2006}} During the 2009 USL First Division season, the [[Carolina RailHawks]], [[Charleston Battery]], [[Vancouver Whitecaps (1986–2010)|Vancouver Whitecaps]], [[Rochester Rhinos]], [[Austin Aztex]], and [[Puerto Rico Islanders]] all wore Umbro kits. During the 2012 USLPro season, the [[Dayton Dutch Lions]] wore Umbro. In October 2007, [[JJB Sports]] bought a 10.1% stake in Umbro in a move to protect its stake in the market for England football shirts.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7053403.stm |title= JJB Sports acquires 10% in Umbro |publisher=BBC News |date=19 October 2007}} ===Nike agreement=== On 23 October 2007, it was announced Umbro had agreed to be bought by [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] in a deal worth {{GBP|285 million}}, the equivalent of 193p per share. The Umbro board recommended to its shareholders they vote in favour of the approach, as it offered a very competitive price for the business. Umbro's share price at the time of the offer was close to 130p.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7057577.stm | work=BBC News | title=Nike to buy Umbro in £285m deal | date=23 October 2007 | accessdate=26 May 2010}} The deal was approved by regulators in December 2007 and concluded in February 2008.[http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/stories/2007/10/22/daily13.html "Nike to buy Umbro" at Portland Business Journal], 23 October 2007 With the objective of revitalising the brand, Umbro launched the "Tailored by England" lines. As of 4 June 2009, Umbro signed a deal with [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] to supply kits for the team. Wearing Umbro kits, Manchester City won its first championship in 34 years.[http://www.umbro.com/en-gb/about-umbro/ "About us" - Umbro website] In 2010, Umbro became sponsor of reformed American team [[New York Cosmos (2010)|New York Cosmos]] to be its exclusive kit supplier.[http://www.sportspromedia.com/news/umbro_sign_deal_with_new_york_cosmos/ "Umbro sign deal with New York Cosmos", SportsPro], 1 October 2010 In May 2012, Nike reported that they would be selling Umbro (along with [[Cole Haan]]) in order to focus on their sports brands, including Nike, [[Converse (shoe company)|Converse]], [[Hurley International|Hurley]] and [[Air Jordan]].[http://www.highsnobiety.com/news/2012/05/31/nike-sells-cole-haan-and-umbro/ "Nike selles Cole Haan and Umbro"], HighSnobiety website, 2012-05-31 In September 2012, The FA announced that future England kits would be manufactured by Nike.{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2012/sep/03/england-nike-kit-umbro |title=England to wear Nike kits for first time after ending Umbro link |publisher=The Guardian |date=3 September 2012}}[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2194408/Nike-replace-Umbro-England-kits.html "England to be kitted in Nike as American giants agree deal to replace Umbro", MailOnline], 27 August 2012[http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/3270/england-national-team/2012/09/03/3350836/england-announce-five-year-kit-deal-with-nike "England announce five-year kit deal with Nike", Goal.com], 3 September 2012 ===Iconix Brand Group=== On October 2012, Nike announced that it had agreed with [[Iconix Brand Group]] to sell Umbro for [[United States dollar|US$]]225 million.[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-10-24/iconix-brand-buys-nike-s-umbro-soccer-unit-for-225-million-1-.html "Iconix Brand Buys Nike’s Umbro Soccer Unit for $225 Million" at Bloomberg.com], 24 October 2012{{cite web | title=NIKE, INC. Announces Sale of Umbro to Iconix Brand Group | url=http://nikeinc.com/news/nike-inc-announces-sale-of-umbro-to-iconix-brand-group | accessdate=20 January 2013 }} The acquisition was completed in December 2012.[http://www.fashinvest.com/iconix-brand-group-completes-acquisition-umbro-nike-225-million/ "Iconix Brand Group Completes Acquisition of Umbro from Nike for $225 Million", Fashion Invest website] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130129115241/http://www.fashinvest.com/iconix-brand-group-completes-acquisition-umbro-nike-225-million/ |date=29 January 2013 }}, 4 December 2012 In February 2014, it was announced that Umbro would supply [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] from the start of the 2014–15 football season.[http://www.evertonfc.com/news/archive/2014/02/04/boss-unveils-new-umbro-partnership/ "Boss Unveils New Umbro Partnership", Everton FC], 4 February 2014 This was the first new club announcement since [[Iconix Brand Group]] bought Umbro, and was followed by the announcement of similar deals with [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] and French clubs [[RC Lens|Lens]] and [[FC Nantes|Nantes]]. On 9 June 2014, [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] announced that their kits for the 2014–15 season would be made by Umbro. Later in 2014, Umbro announced deals to supply a number of teams, including the [[Serbian national football team]], the [[Malawi national football team]], [[CR Vasco da Gama|Vasco da Gama]] and [[Grêmio Foot-Ball Porto Alegrense|Grêmio]]. In February 2015, Dutch [[Eredivisie]] champions [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]] announced a new kit deal with Umbro, replacing PSV's previous deal with Nike, which had been in existence since 1994. The deal coincided with PSV's return to the [[UEFA Champions League]] after a six-year absence.[http://www.footyheadlines.com/2015/02/psv-eindhoven-announce-five-year-umbro-kit-deal.html PSV Eindhoven Announce Five-Year Umbro Kit Deal], 17 February 2015 In late April 2015, [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] announced a new five-year agreement with Umbro as the club's official technical partner. This agreement included creating a commemorative kit for the Hammers' final year in the historic [[Boleyn Ground]].[http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2015/April/30-April/West-Ham-re-united-with-Umbro/ "West Ham re-united with Umbro", West Ham United FC], 30 April 2015 In early December 2015, German club [[1. FC Nürnberg]] announced a long-term kit deal with Umbro as the club's official kit supplier, replacing [[Adidas]].[http://www.footyheadlines.com/2015/12/umbro-and-1-fc-nurnberg-sign-long-term-kit-deal.html Umbro and 1. FC Nürnberg Sign Long-Term Kit Deal], 3 December 2015 In May 2016, it was announced that Umbro had become the technical sponsor of [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]]{{cite web|title=Rovers return to Umbro|url=http://www.rovers.co.uk/news/article/blackburn-rovers-umbro-3108853.aspx|website=Blackburn Rovers official website|accessdate=2 June 2016}} in a five-year deal. And would also return to making [[A.F.C. Bournemouth]] kit after two separate occasions in the 70’s and 80’s for the 2017-18 season. In June 2017, seven-times German Champion FC Schalke 04 announced a five-year deal with Umbro replacing Adidas after 55 years. ==Products== [[File:Shirt 2014.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Colombian team [[Independiente Santa Fe|Santa Fe]] shirt designed by Umbro for 2014 season.]] Umbro currently focuses on [[Association football|football]] equipment, such as [[Kit (association football)|kit uniforms (jerseys, shorts and socks)]], [[Kit (association football)#Other equipment|goalkeeper gloves]], [[Ball (association football)|balls]] and [[Football boots|boots]], apart of manufacturing other [[clothing|apparel]] such as [[t-shirt]]s and jackets.[http://www.umbro.com/en-gb/shop/ Umbro products] on Umbro official website, retrieved 12 Feb 2017 Until the mid-1980s, the company manufactured only sports clothing, in particular football jerseys, shorts and socks, but had no footwear range. Eventually, in 1985, Umbro decided to introduce its first football boot into the Brazilian market. This design, cheaper than the products of existing boot brands such as [[Adidas]], proved popular and went into mass production internationally two years later. Umbro also manufactured a popular style of [[shorts]] that reached its peak in the United States in the late 1980s and early 1990s. They were made of [[nylon]], had a drawstring waistband, and often came in bright colours. With the growth of youth soccer leagues in the U.S. in the 1980s, many youths, teens and young adults began wearing them as everyday clothing. At the height of the "Umbro fashion," other brands of soccer shorts, such as Adidas, [[Diadora]], [[Hummel International|Hummel]], [[Lotto Sport Italia|Lotto]] and [[Mitre Sports International|Mitre]], also became popular. Its major competitors in this market include Reebok, Nike, Adidas, [[Puma AG|Puma]] and fellow italian manufacturer [[Lotto Sport Italia|Lotto]]. Other releases by Umbro include the Stealth boot,{{cite web|title=Umbro Stealth Booth|url=http://www.soccercleats101.com/2010/04/12/umbro-stealth-pro-review/|publisher=SoccerCleats101.com|accessdate=12 April 2010}} released in 2010 and worn by players such as [[Gaël Clichy]] and [[Phil Jagielka]]. The same year, the company released the GT, worn by then-[[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] striker [[Darren Bent]]. The company announced it as "its lightest ever boot." This was succeeded by the GT II model.[http://www.soccerbible.com/news/football-boots/archive/2012/09/27/umbro-gt-ii-pro-football-boots-green-carbon-white.aspx Umbro GT II at FootballBible.com] June 2011 saw the release of the Umbro Geometra Pro.{{cite web|title=Umbro Geometra|url=http://www.footy-boots.com/umbro-geometra-pro/|publisher=Footy-Boots.com|accessdate=17 June 2011}} In 2013, Umbro introduced to a new wave of releases that included the Speciali IV and the Geometra II.{{cite web|title=Umbro Geometra II|url=http://www.soccercleats101.com/2013/04/29/umbro-geometra-pro-ii-review/|publisher=SoccerCleats101.com|accessdate=4 April 2013}} Following the purchase of the brand by [[Iconix Brand Group]] in 2013, the first major product release from Umbro was the UX-1,{{cite web|title=Umbro UX-1 II|url=http://www.soccerbible.com/performance/football-boots/2014/11/umbro-launch-ux-1-concept/|publisher=Soccerbible.com|accessdate=7 January 2015}} a technologically advanced football boot which was voted as one of the best new releases of the year.{{cite web|title=Umbro UX-1 II|url=http://www.soccerpro.com/theinstep/umbro-ux-1-review/|publisher=Soccerpro.com|accessdate=7 January 2015}} ==Sponsorships== Umbro is the official supplier and sponsor of numerous [[association football]] teams, players and associations, including: ===Associations=== * {{flagicon|AUS}} [[FFA Cup]] *
