{{use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Estadio Vicente Calderón | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Aprobado el nuevo ámbito Mahou-Calderón (01).jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = '''[[UEFA stadium categories|UEFA]]''' {{rating|4|4}} | fullname = Estadio Vicente Calderón | former_names = Estadio Manzanares
(1966–71) | location = [[Arganzuela]], [[Madrid]], [[Spain]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|24|6.19|N|3|43|14.18|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = 3 August 1959 | opened = 2 October 1966 | renovated = 1972, 1982 | expanded = | closed = 2017 | demolished = 2018 (To Be Demolished) | suites = | architect = Javier Barroso
Miguel Ángel García Lomas | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 54,907{{cite web|url=http://clubatleticodemadrid.com/galerias/el-punto-de-encuentro-de-los-atleticos-de-todo-el-mundo?modo=vertical|title=Vicente Calderón|publisher=}} | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = {{convert|105|x|70|m|yd|abbr=on}} | acreage = | tenants = [[Atlético Madrid]] (1966–2017) }} The '''Vicente Calderón Stadium''' ({{lang-es|Estadio Vicente Calderón}} {{IPA-es|esˈtaðjo βiˈθente kaldeˈɾon|}}) was the home stadium of [[Atlético Madrid]] since its completion in 1966 to 2017, with a current seating capacity of 54,907 and located on the banks of the [[Manzanares River|Manzanares]], in the [[Arganzuela]] district of [[Madrid]], Spain. The stadium was originally called the ''Estadio Manzanares'', but this was later changed to the Vicente Calderón Stadium, in honour of their long-term President [[Vicente Calderón]].{{cite web|url=http://en.clubatleticodemadrid.com/atm/instalations|title=Vicente Calderón Stadium|publisher=AtléticodeMadrid|accessdate=30 January 2016}} ==History== [[File:Vicente-Calderon-030612-1.jpg|thumb|right|North external view of the stadium.]] [[File:Estadio Vicente Calderón, 2014.JPG|thumb|right|South external view of the stadium.]] [[File:Vicente-Calderon-1-070910.jpg|thumb|right|Northwest internal view of the stadium.]] [[File:Estadio Vicente Calderón - 02.jpg|thumb|right|South end stand view of the stadium.]] To finance the new stadium, Atlético Madrid had to make a debt issue in 1958 in the form of mortgage bonds that were underwritten mostly by club shareholders and members. {{citation needed|date=March 2015}} On 17 March 1961, Javier Barroso bought land for the construction of a new stadium, to replace the [[Estadio Metropolitano de Madrid]]. In the same year, work began on the new stadium. {{citation needed|date=March 2015}} The ground opened in 1966, and was named the Estadio del Manzanares until 1972.{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/teams/spain/club-atletico-de-madrid/2020/venue/|title=Estadio Vicente Calderón|work=Soccerway|publisher=Perform|accessdate=30 January 2016}} A notable and rather spectacular feature of the Vicente Calderón is that the [[Autopista de Circunvalación M-30|M-30]] dual carriageway, running from the South Node Toledo Bridge, passes below one of the main stands. ===Departure of Atlético === On 30 July 2007, Atlético Madrid, [[Mahou-San Miguel Group|Mahou]] brewery and Ayuntamiento de Madrid signed an agreement to reclassify the land that is currently occupied by the Vicente Calderón stadium and the Mahou brewery, agreeing that Atlético would move within three years to the Estadio Olímpico de Madrid, better known as [[Wanda Metropolitano|Estadio La Peineta]] (officially [[Wanda Metropolitano]]), which was to be renovated in preparation for Atlético's tenancy. After reconstruction, La Peineta holds 67,000 spectators and features fully covered stands. The Vicente Calderón Stadium is soon to be demolished, and a park will be built in its place, which is to be named the 'Park Atlético Madrid'. Atlético then moved to La Peineta in the [[2017-18 La Liga|2017-18 season]]. The decision to demolish the stadium was not well received by some of the Atlético fans who were against the relocation of the club, as they considered it to be a bad move if money was not being used to improve the club itself. The protests were led by the Save the Calderon Group and the Atlético Supporters Club: Asociación Señales de Humo.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}} ==Access== The Estadio Vicente Calderón is located on the banks of the [[Manzanares (river)|Manzanares]].{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/madrid/sport-and-fitness/estadio-vicente-calderon|title=Estadio Vicente Calderón|date=10 April 2014|publisher=Time Out|accessdate=21 March 2015}} In addition, the stadium can be accessed via the [[Madrid Metro]]. The closest stations are: Pirámides Station and Marqués de Vadillo Station, both of which are on Line 5 of the [[Madrid Metro]].http://www.terra.es/deportes/articulo/html/dpo67455.htm terra.es ==Copa del Rey finals== The stadium hosted the final of the [[Copa del Rey]] (also previously known as the ''Copa del Generalísimo'') on 14 occasions:
[[1973 Copa del Generalísimo Final|1973]] * [[1974 Copa del Generalísimo Final|1974]] * [[1975 Copa del Generalísimo Final|1975]] * [[1977 Copa del Rey Final|1977]] * [[1979 Copa del Rey Final|1979]] * [[1981 Copa del Rey Final|1981]] * [[1986 Copa del Rey Final|1986]] * [[1989 Copa del Rey Final|1989]] * [[1994 Copa del Rey Final|1994]] * [[2005 Copa del Rey Final|2005]] * [[2008 Copa del Rey Final|2008]] * [[2012 Copa del Rey Final|2012]] * [[2016 Copa del Rey Final|2016]] * [[2017 Copa del Rey Final|2017]]. ==International matches== ===Spain national team matches=== Vicente Calderón hosted eleven international matches of the [[Spain national football team|Spanish national team]]. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Data !! Opponent !! Score !! Competition |- | 23 May 1972 || {{fb|Uruguay}} || align="center" bgcolor=#bbf3ff|2–0 || [[Friendly match]] |- | 24 April 1975 || {{fb|West Germany}} || align="center" bgcolor=#ffffbb|1–1 || [[UEFA Euro 1976 qualifying]] |- | 26 October 1977 || {{fb|Romania|1965}} || align="center" bgcolor=#bbf3ff|2–0 || [[1978 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|1978 FIFA World Cup qualification]] |- | 18 February 1981 || {{fb|France}} || align="center" bgcolor=#bbf3ff|1–0 || [[Friendly match]] |- | 20 September 1995 || {{fb|Argentina}} || align="center" bgcolor=#bbf3ff|2–1 || [[Friendly match]] |- | 30 April 2003 || {{fb|Ecuador}} || align="center" bgcolor=#bbf3ff|4–0 || [[Friendly match]] |- | 7 September 2005 || {{fb|Serbia and Montenegro}} || align="center" bgcolor=#ffffbb|1–1 || [[2006 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|2006 FIFA World Cup qualification]] |- | 12 November 2005 || {{fb|Slovakia}} || align="center" bgcolor=#bbf3ff|5–1 || [[2006 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA play-off)|2006 FIFA World Cup qualification play-off]] |- | 14 November 2009 || {{fb|Argentina}} || align="center" bgcolor=#bbf3ff|2–1 || [[Friendly match]] |- | 16 October 2012 || {{fb|France}} || align="center" bgcolor=#ffffbb|1–1 || [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|2014 FIFA World Cup qualification]] |- | 5 March 2014 || {{fb|Italy}} || align="center" bgcolor=#bbf3ff|1–0 || [[Friendly match]] |} ===1982 FIFA World Cup=== The stadium hosted the group D three matches. Group D was one of four groups of national teams competing in the second stage of the [[1982 FIFA World Cup]]. {{football box |date=28 June 1982 |time=17:15 [[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] |team1={{fb-rt|AUT}} |score=0–1 |report=[https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/matches/round=294/match=767/index.html Report] |team2={{fb|FRA}} |goals2=[[Bernard Genghini|Genghini]] {{goal|39}} |stadium=Estadio Vicente Calderón, [[Madrid]] |attendance=37,000 |referee=[[Károly Palotai]] ([[Hungarian Football Federation|Hungary]]) }} {{football box |date=1 July 1982 |time=17:15 [[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] |team1={{fb-rt|AUT}} |score=2–2 |report=[https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/matches/round=294/match=771/index.html Report] |team2={{fb|NIR}} |goals1=[[Bruno Pezzey|Pezzey]] {{goal|50}}
[[Reinhold Hintermaier|Hintermaier]] {{goal|68}} |goals2=[[Billy Hamilton (footballer)|Hamilton]] {{goal|27||75}} |stadium=Estadio Vicente Calderón, [[Madrid]] |attendance=20,000 |referee=[[Adolf Prokop]] ([[Deutscher Fußball-Verband der DDR|East Germany]]) }} {{football box |date=4 July 1982 |time=17:15 [[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] |team1={{fb-rt|FRA}} |score=4–1 |report=[https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/matches/round=294/match=920/index.html Report] |team2={{fb|NIR}} |goals1=[[Alain Giresse|Giresse]] {{goal|33||80}}
[[Dominique Rocheteau|Rocheteau]] {{goal|46||68}} |goals2=[[Gerry Armstrong (footballer)|Armstrong]] {{goal|75}} |stadium=Estadio Vicente Calderón, [[Madrid]] |attendance=37,000 |referee=[[Alojzy Jarguz]] ([[Polish Football Association|Poland]]) }} {{wide image|Estadio Vicente Calderón en el Atlético de Madrid-Schalke 04 (2008).jpg|1100px|Panoramic view of the stadium}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category}} {{Portal|Association football|Spain}} *[http://www.estadiosdeespana.com/posts/madrid-estadio-vicente-calderon/ Estadios de España] *[http://www.stadiumguide.com/vicentecalderon/ Stadium Guide Article] *[http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/europe/spain/madrid/madrid_vicente_calderon.shtml Stadium photos at World Stadiums] {{Atlético Madrid}} {{La Liga venues}} {{1982 FIFA World Cup stadiums}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vicente Calderon}} [[Category:Atlético Madrid]] [[Category:Football venues in the Community of Madrid]] [[Category:Sports venues in Madrid]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1966]] [[Category:1982 FIFA World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Arganzuela District, Madrid]]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Šiauliai Arena | logo_image = [[File:Šiauliai Arena logo.png|180px]] | image = [[Image:SiauliuArena.jpg|250px]] | nickname = | address = J. Jablonskio g. 16 | location = [[Šiauliai]], [[Lithuania]] | broke_ground = 2006 | opened = July 25, 2007 | owner = | construction_cost = 27 million [[USD]] | contractor = | architect = Eugenijus Miliūnas | tenants = [[BC Šiauliai]] | seating_capacity = [[Basketball]] 5,700
[[Concert]]s 7,400 | website ={{URL|siauliuarena.lt}} }} '''Šiauliai Arena''' is the largest [[arena]] in [[Šiauliai]], [[Lithuania]]. It generally hosts basketball games as well as concerts. The basketball club [[BC Šiauliai]], which currently competes in the domestic [[Lietuvos Krepšinio Lyga|LKL]] and [[ULEB Cup]], uses the facility for all of its European and LKL home fixtures. It opened on July 25, 2007. The arena had hosted the [[Eurobasket 2011]] [[EuroBasket 2011 Group B|Group B]] matches from 31 August 2011 to 5 September 2011. In 2013 Šiauliai Arena hosted [[Davis Cup]] matches. ==Building== Holographic glass shining in the sun on the outside throughout four out of five floors makes the arena stand out from the other buildings. The Šiauliai Arena is capable to accommodate 7,400 people during the concerts, while it features 5,700 seats for basketball games. The arena was built by ''Panevėžio statybos trestas'' from [[Panevėžys]] in 18 months. The total cost exceeded 75 million [[Litas]] (27 million [[USD]]). The parking lot next to the arena has the capacity for 600 cars. ==Gallery== Image:SiauliuArenavidus.jpg|Šiauliai Arena from inside. Image:Siauliu_arena.JPG|Basketball game at the arena. ==External links== * {{official|http://www.siauliuarena.lt/}} {{coord|55|55|12|N|23|16|58|E|type:landmark|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Siauliai Arena}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Lithuania]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Lithuania]] [[Category:Sport in Šiauliai]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2007]] [[Category:FIBA EuroBasket 2011 venues]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Šiauliai]] [[Category:Tennis venues in Lithuania]] {{Lithuania-sports-venue-stub}}
